						<h1 class="page-title">Hm. Looks like something went wrong&hellip;</h1>
				</header>
		<section id="content-container">
			
				<article id="post-0" class="post no-results not-found">

					<div class="entry-content">
						<p>It seems we can’t find what you’re looking for. If you are looking for a specific post, try searching up in the right-hand corner. Otherwise take a look at our most recent posts below.</p>
					</div><!-- .entry-content -->

		<h1 class="index-title">

		</h1>
	
	</header><!-- .entry-header -->

	<div class="index-content">
		<p><img class="wp-image-2039 alignleft" src="http://italian.berkeley.edu/wp-content/uploads/2014/09/Spackman-Accidental-Orientalists-198x300.jpg" alt="" width="210" height="319" srcset="http://italian.berkeley.edu/wp-content/uploads/2014/09/Spackman-Accidental-Orientalists-198x300.jpg 198w, http://italian.berkeley.edu/wp-content/uploads/2014/09/Spackman-Accidental-Orientalists-768x1163.jpg 768w, http://italian.berkeley.edu/wp-content/uploads/2014/09/Spackman-Accidental-Orientalists-676x1024.jpg 676w" sizes="(max-width: 210px) 100vw, 210px" />Professor <a href="http://italian.berkeley.edu/people/barbara-spackman/">Barbara Spackman</a> has published a new book in July 2017: <a href="https://liverpooluniversitypress.co.uk/products/87381"><em>Accidental Orientalists: Modern Italian Travelers in Ottoman Lands</em></a>, Liverpool University Press</p>

<article id="post-1839" class="group index-post-container">
				<figure class="the-thumbnail">
				<a href="http://italian.berkeley.edu/2016/11/16/2015-16-distinguished-teaching-award-barbara-spackman/" title="Permalink to 2015-16 Distinguished Teaching Award: Barbara Spackman" rel="bookmark">
					<img width="151" height="209" src="http://italian.berkeley.edu/wp-content/uploads/2014/08/spackman.jpg" class="attachment-index-thumb size-index-thumb wp-post-image" alt="" />				</a>
			</figure>
				<header class="index-header">
		<h1 class="index-title">
			<a href="http://italian.berkeley.edu/2016/11/16/2015-16-distinguished-teaching-award-barbara-spackman/" title="Permalink to 2015-16 Distinguished Teaching Award: Barbara Spackman" rel="bookmark">	
				2015-16 Distinguished Teaching Award: Barbara Spackman			</a>
		</h1>
	
	</header><!-- .entry-header -->

	<div class="index-content">
		<p>Congratulations to Professor <a href="http://italian.berkeley.edu/people/barbara-spackman/">Barbara Spackman</a>, Italian Studies and Comparative Literature, who received the 2015-2016 Distinguished Teaching Award for Senate Faculty Members.</p>
	</div><!-- .entry-content -->


</article><!-- #post-1839 -->




<article id="post-1279" class="group index-post-container">
		<header class="index-header">
		<h1 class="index-title">
			<a href="http://italian.berkeley.edu/2016/03/01/site-internship-program-apply-now/" title="Permalink to SITE Internship Program" rel="bookmark">	
				SITE Internship Program			</a>
		</h1>
	
	</header><!-- .entry-header -->

	<div class="index-content">
		<p>The <a href="http://siteprogram.wix.com/site">Study Intercultural Training Experience (SITE) internship</a> is a <strong>paid internship</strong> program based in Lombardy, Italy. It is aimed to recent graduates who have a good command of Italian and who are interested in working as teaching assistants in Lombard high schools for one or two semesters.</p>
<p> <a href="http://italian.berkeley.edu/2016/03/01/site-internship-program-apply-now/#more-1279" class="more-link"> &raquo;  read more  &raquo;</a></p>
	</div><!-- .entry-content -->


</article><!-- #post-1279 -->

        $(this).parent().attr("title",function(i,val){
            return val == alt ? "" : alt;
        });
    });
});

<article id="post-1279" class="group post-container">
	<header class="entry-header">
		<h1 class="entry-title">SITE Internship Program</h1>
	</header><!-- .entry-header -->

	<div class="entry-content">
		
				
	
		<p>The <a href="http://siteprogram.wix.com/site">Study Intercultural Training Experience (SITE) internship</a> is a <strong>paid internship</strong> program based in Lombardy, Italy. It is aimed to recent graduates who have a good command of Italian and who are interested in working as teaching assistants in Lombard high schools for one or two semesters.</p>
<p><span id="more-1279"></span></p>
<p>If you are interested in perfecting your knowledge and understanding of Italian language and culture, while gaining valuable teaching experience abroad, this program is for you!</p>
<p>This great opportunity for linguistic and intercultural exchange is open to seniors and to former students who have graduated from UC Berkeley within the last 18 months. Students enrolled in a MA or PhD program of Italian language and culture can also apply.</p>
<p><a href="http://siteprogram.wix.com/site#%21requirements/s5knb">Eligibility and Requirements</a></p>
<p><a href="http://siteprogram.wix.com/site#%21how-to-apply/ikfng">How to Apply</a></p>
<p>For more information, visit the <a href="http://italian.berkeley.edu/undergraduate-program/site-internship-program/">SITE Program&#8217;s description here.</a></p>
<p>&nbsp;</p>
			</div><!-- .entry-content -->

	<footer class="footer-meta">
		
		
	</footer><!-- .entry-meta -->
</article><!-- #post-1279 -->

			

			</div>
		</div><!-- #content-container -->



	</div><!-- #main -->

						<h1 class="page-title">Hm. Looks like something went wrong&hellip;</h1>
				</header>
		<section id="content-container">
			
				<article id="post-0" class="post no-results not-found">

					<div class="entry-content">
						<p>It seems we can’t find what you’re looking for. If you are looking for a specific post, try searching up in the right-hand corner. Otherwise take a look at our most recent posts below.</p>
					</div><!-- .entry-content -->
				</article><!-- #post-0 -->

		</h1>
	
	</header><!-- .entry-header -->

	<div class="index-content">
		<p><img class="wp-image-2039 alignleft" src="http://italian.berkeley.edu/wp-content/uploads/2014/09/Spackman-Accidental-Orientalists-198x300.jpg" alt="" width="210" height="319" srcset="http://italian.berkeley.edu/wp-content/uploads/2014/09/Spackman-Accidental-Orientalists-198x300.jpg 198w, http://italian.berkeley.edu/wp-content/uploads/2014/09/Spackman-Accidental-Orientalists-768x1163.jpg 768w, http://italian.berkeley.edu/wp-content/uploads/2014/09/Spackman-Accidental-Orientalists-676x1024.jpg 676w" sizes="(max-width: 210px) 100vw, 210px" />Professor <a href="http://italian.berkeley.edu/people/barbara-spackman/">Barbara Spackman</a> has published a new book in July 2017: <a href="https://liverpooluniversitypress.co.uk/products/87381"><em>Accidental Orientalists: Modern Italian Travelers in Ottoman Lands</em></a>, Liverpool University Press</p>

		</h1>
	
	</header><!-- .entry-header -->

	<div class="index-content">
		<p><img class="size-medium wp-image-1849 alignleft" src="http://italian.berkeley.edu/wp-content/uploads/2016/11/Steimatsky-book-2017-210x300.jpg" alt="steimatsky-book-2017" width="210" height="300" srcset="http://italian.berkeley.edu/wp-content/uploads/2016/11/Steimatsky-book-2017-210x300.jpg 210w, http://italian.berkeley.edu/wp-content/uploads/2016/11/Steimatsky-book-2017.jpg 385w" sizes="(max-width: 210px) 100vw, 210px" />Visiting Scholar <a href="http://italian.berkeley.edu/people/noa-steimatsky/">Noa Steimatsky</a> published a new book in January 2017: <a href="https://global.oup.com/academic/product/the-face-on-film-9780199863167?cc=us&amp;lang=en&amp;"><em>The Face on Film</em></a>, Oxford University Press</p>

<article id="post-1839" class="group index-post-container">
				<figure class="the-thumbnail">
				<a href="http://italian.berkeley.edu/2016/11/16/2015-16-distinguished-teaching-award-barbara-spackman/" title="Permalink to 2015-16 Distinguished Teaching Award: Barbara Spackman" rel="bookmark">
					<img width="151" height="209" src="http://italian.berkeley.edu/wp-content/uploads/2014/08/spackman.jpg" class="attachment-index-thumb size-index-thumb wp-post-image" alt="" />				</a>
			</figure>
				<header class="index-header">
		<h1 class="index-title">
			<a href="http://italian.berkeley.edu/2016/11/16/2015-16-distinguished-teaching-award-barbara-spackman/" title="Permalink to 2015-16 Distinguished Teaching Award: Barbara Spackman" rel="bookmark">	
				2015-16 Distinguished Teaching Award: Barbara Spackman			</a>
		</h1>
	
	</header><!-- .entry-header -->

	<div class="index-content">
		<p>Congratulations to Professor <a href="http://italian.berkeley.edu/people/barbara-spackman/">Barbara Spackman</a>, Italian Studies and Comparative Literature, who received the 2015-2016 Distinguished Teaching Award for Senate Faculty Members.</p>
	</div><!-- .entry-content -->


</article><!-- #post-1839 -->




<article id="post-1279" class="group index-post-container">
		<header class="index-header">
		<h1 class="index-title">
			<a href="http://italian.berkeley.edu/2016/03/01/site-internship-program-apply-now/" title="Permalink to SITE Internship Program" rel="bookmark">	
				SITE Internship Program			</a>
		</h1>
	
	</header><!-- .entry-header -->

	<div class="index-content">
		<p>The <a href="http://siteprogram.wix.com/site">Study Intercultural Training Experience (SITE) internship</a> is a <strong>paid internship</strong> program based in Lombardy, Italy. It is aimed to recent graduates who have a good command of Italian and who are interested in working as teaching assistants in Lombard high schools for one or two semesters.</p>
<p> <a href="http://italian.berkeley.edu/2016/03/01/site-internship-program-apply-now/#more-1279" class="more-link"> &raquo;  read more  &raquo;</a></p>
	</div><!-- .entry-content -->


</article><!-- #post-1279 -->

        $(this).parent().attr("title",function(i,val){
            return val == alt ? "" : alt;
        });
    });
});

<header id="site-header" class="courses wideness" role="banner">
	 <h1><a href="http://italian.berkeley.edu">  Courses for Non-UCB Students</a></h1>
			<nav id="main-nav" role="navigation">
				<div class="menu-header-menu-container"><ul id="menu-header-menu" class="sf-menu"><li id="menu-item-1554" class="menu-item menu-item-type-post_type menu-item-object-page menu-item-has-children menu-item-1554"><a href="http://italian.berkeley.edu/news-events/upcoming-events/">News &#038; Events</a>
<ul class="sub-menu">

								<div id="sidebar" class="widget-area" role="complementary">
						<div class="menu-courses-sidebar-container"><ul id="menu-courses-sidebar" class="menu"><li id="menu-item-1932" class="menu-item menu-item-type-taxonomy menu-item-object-courses-timeframe menu-item-1932"><a href="http://italian.berkeley.edu/courses-timeframe/2017-fall/">Fall 2017</a></li>

<li id="menu-item-1570" class="menu-item menu-item-type-post_type menu-item-object-page menu-item-1570"><a href="http://italian.berkeley.edu/courses-archive/">Courses Archive</a></li>
</ul></div>		</div><!-- #secondary .widget-area -->

						
							
<article id="post-754" class="group post-container entry-content">
	
				
	<header class="entry-header">
		<h1 class="entry-title">Courses for Non-UCB Students</h1>
	</header><!-- .entry-header -->

	<div class="entry-content-wrapper">
		<p><strong>During the Summer</strong></p>
<p>Our summer courses are generally open for registration by anyone &#8212; not just UC Berkeley students.  We offer a variety of language and culture courses each summer, taught by qualified UCB instructors.  All summer course registration goes through the Berkeley Summer Sessions office, whose <a href="http://summer.berkeley.edu">website</a> outlines the enrollment process, tuition fees, and more.</p>
<p><strong>During the Academic Year</strong></p>
<p>While we are unable to offer traditional &#8220;auditing&#8221; or &#8220;sitting in on&#8221; a Fall or Spring course, the UC Extension makes it possible for non-UC Berkeley students to enroll in UC Berkeley classes through their Concurrent Enrollment program, pending instructor approval.</p>
<p>Courses through Concurrent Enrollment can be taken for credit/letter grade, pass/no pass, or no credit; registration costs vary depending on the grading option.  For details on Concurrent Enrollment requirements, deadlines, applications and fees, please visit <a href="http://extension.berkeley.edu/static/studentservices/concurrent/">their web site</a> or call 510-642-4111.</p>
<p>For registration purposes, you will need the course control number from UC Berkeley&#8217;s official <a href="http://schedule.berkeley.edu/%20">online schedule of classes</a>.</p>
<p>A few weeks before the class begins, it is important that the potential Concurrent Enrollment student e-mails the instructor of the course to introduce him or herself and informs the instructor of his or her plans.  Course descriptions with instructor names are posted in the Courses section of this web site.  In order to contact our instructors, please see the <a href="http://italian.berkeley.edu/people-category/core-faculty/">People</a> page of this website.</p>
<p>If the course you want to take is an Italian language course, especially if you are unsure which level is right for you, please contact our <a title="Giuliana Perco" href="http://italian.berkeley.edu/people/giuliana-perco/">language coordinator</a> for approval and information about a language assessment.</p>
<p>In general, applications for Concurrent Enrollment are not officially approved and signed by the instructor until the first week of class, as part of the approval is based on the number of spaces available.  Once approved by the instructor, the application will go through an approval process between the UCB campus and the Concurrent Enrollment office, and finally the student will be officially enrolled and billed by the UC Extension.</p>
	</div><!-- .entry-content-wrapper -->
</article><!-- #post-754 -->

										</div>
			</div><!-- #content -->



	</div><!-- #main -->

        $(this).parent().attr("title",function(i,val){
            return val == alt ? "" : alt;
        });

});

			<div id="regular-content">
<a name="language"></a>
			
				<h2 class="course-category-title">Language Courses</h2>
				
					<article id="post-1933" class="group individual-course-container">
						<header class="course-header">
							<h1 class="course-title">
			<a href="http://italian.berkeley.edu/courses/elementary-italian-13/" title="Permalink to Elementary Italian" rel="bookmark">	
				1: Elementary Italian			</a>
		</h1>
	
						</header><!-- .entry-header -->

						<div class="index-content">
						
							<p class="section-spacing">
								<b>Section 1: </b>								MW 8-10, F 9-10 | 206 Dwinelle  | <b>Instructor: Chiara Cecchelli</b>							</p>

								<p class="section-spacing"><b>Section 2: </b> 								M-F 9-10 | 179 Dwinelle | <b>Instructor: Michiko Arai</b>								</p>
								<p class="section-spacing"><b>Section 3: </b> 								M-F 10-11 | 179 Dwinelle | <b>Instructor: Kristen Keach</b>								</p>								
								<p class="section-spacing"><b>Section 4: </b> 								M-F 11-12 | 183 Dwinelle | <b>Instructor: Zachary Bekowies</b>								</p>								
								
								<p class="section-spacing five"><b>Section 5: </b> 								M-F 1-2 | 130 Dwinelle | <b>Instructor: Nicole Trigg</b>								</p>								
								
																																
								
																																
								
																								
							<p class="ls-breadth"><span class="units">Units: 5</span>
										</p>
						</div><!-- .entry-content -->

					</article><!-- #post-1933 -->
	
					
					<article id="post-1934" class="group individual-course-container">

		</h1>
	
						</header><!-- .entry-header -->

						<div class="index-content">
						
							<p class="section-spacing">
								Th 2-5 | 6331 Dwinelle  | <b>Instructor: Giuliana Perco</b>								
							</p>
								
							<p class="ls-breadth"><span class="units">Units: 4</span>
										</p>

		</section><!-- #content-container -->

        $(this).parent().attr("title",function(i,val){
            return val == alt ? "" : alt;

<article id="post-1114" class="group post-container entry-content">
	<header class="entry-header">
		<h1 class="entry-title"> 1S: Intensive Italian for Spanish Speakers</h1>
		<p class="section-spacing">
																M-F 10-11 <a href="http://italian.berkeley.edu/courses-timeframe/2016-spring/" rel="tag">Spring 2016</a> | 206 Dwinellle  | <b>Instructor: Annamaria Bellezza</b>							</p>

																								
																																
																																
								
																																
								
																																
								
																																
								
																								
							<p class="ls-breadth"><span class="units">

							Units: 6</span>
										</p>
	</header><!-- .entry-header -->

	<div class="entry-content-wrapper">

	
		<p><strong>NEW INTENSIVE COURSE!<br />
EQUIVALENT OF ITALIAN STUDIES 1 AND 2 COMBINED</strong></p>
<p><strong>FOR NATIVE SPEAKERS OF SPANISH OR THOSE WITH COLLEGE LEVEL SPANISH 4 OR HIGHER (EXCEPTIONS MADE WITH DEPARTMENTAL CONSENT)</strong></p>
<p>This course is specifically designed with the needs and strengths of native or proficient speakers of Spanish in mind, so that the similarities between the two languages can be used to promote specific learning paths. This is an intensive Italian language course, which combines TWO semesters in ONE, covering all the materials usually covered in Italian Studies 1 and 2 of Elementary Italian. The course provides an accelerated introduction to Italian, allowing students who successfully complete it to enroll in Italian 3, gaining faster access to Upper Division courses. The general objectives are to provide students with the basic tools for oral and written communication in Italian, but also to offer them the opportunity to learn about Italian culture, to reflect on intercultural differences and similarities, and to become more aware ‘multilingual subjects’ in our plurilingual society.</p>
<p><strong>Workload</strong>: This course is comprised of a master lecture class, meeting 5 times per week, and a drill/conversation section, meeting 2 times per week. Regular and continued attendance of both classes is mandatory. Due to the intensive nature of this course, students should plan to study one to two hours a day and be committed to a fast-paced learning environment.</p>
<p><strong>Texts:</strong><br />
<a href="http://vistahigherlearning.com/store/ucberkeley.htm/sentieri-2nd-edition.html"><em>Sentieri</em></a>, 2nd edition, Julia M. Cozzarelli, Vista Higher Learning Publishing, 2015. ISBN 978-1-62680-803-4<strong><br />
</strong></p>
<p>An Italian dictionary for purchase to be announced by the instructor.</p>
<p><strong>Sections:</strong><br />
Section 101, MW 1-2, B33B Dwinelle. CCN: 46921<br />
Section 102, MW 2-3, B33B Dwinelle. CCN: 46924</p>

	</div><!-- .entry-content-wrapper -->

</article><!-- #post-1114 -->

			
		
		</div><!-- #content-container -->



	</div><!-- #main -->

<li id="menu-item-1441" class="menu-item menu-item-type-post_type menu-item-object-page menu-item-1441"><a href="http://italian.berkeley.edu/undergraduate-program/">Academics</a></li>

<article id="post-1936" class="group post-container entry-content">
	<header class="entry-header">
		<h1 class="entry-title"> 3: Intermediate Italian</h1>
		<p class="section-spacing">
																M-F 11-12 <a href="http://italian.berkeley.edu/courses-timeframe/2017-fall/" rel="tag">Fall 2017</a> | 130 Dwinelle  | <b>Instructor: Mara Mauri-Jacobsen</b>							</p>

																								
																																
																																
								
																																
								
																																
								
																																
								
																								
							<p class="ls-breadth"><span class="units">

							Units: 5</span>
										</p>
	</header><!-- .entry-header -->

	<div class="entry-content-wrapper">

	
		<p><strong>Course conducted <u>entirely</u> in Italian</strong></p>
<p>In this course students will review and expand the grammar structures learned in the previous year. They will also be exposed to more examples of Italian culture through authentic materials such as short stories, newspaper articles, films, and plays. Students will continue to build on the skills acquired in Italian 2, striving for a higher level of sophistication and fluency in writing, reading, listening and speaking. Conducted in Italian.</p>
<p><strong>Course Requirements:</strong>  Five hours per week. Weekly quizzes, midterm, oral exam, presentation, and a final exam. Regular daily attendance is required.</p>
<p><strong>Required texts:</strong></p>
<div class="gmail_default"><a href="http://www.mypearsonstore.com/bookstore/caleidoscopio-books-a-la-carte-edition-9780205255689"><i>Caleidoscopio</i></a>, Daniela Bartalesi-Graf and Colleen Ryan, Pearson, 2015. I<span class="m_540052908979182681gmail-isbn13">SBN-13: 978-0-205-25568-9</span></div>
<p><em>Webster&#8217;s New World Italian Dictionary </em>Concise edition ISBN 9780139536397</p>
<p><strong>Recommended texts:</strong></p>
<p><em>English Grammar for Students of Italian, </em>3rd edition- S. Adorni, K Primorac. Olivia and Hill. ISBN 9780934034401</p>
<p><strong>Recommended texts:</strong></p>
<p><em>Webster&#8217;s New World Italian Dictionary </em>Concise edition ISBN 9780139536397</p>
<p><strong>Prerequisite:</strong>  Italian 2 at UCB or <a href="http://italian.berkeley.edu/undergraduate-program/language-study-and-placement/">placement test</a>. Please contact Dr. Perco if you have questions regarding placement in this course: <a href="mailto:gperco@berkeley.edu"><u>gperco@berkeley.edu</u></a>.</p>

	</div><!-- .entry-content-wrapper -->

</article><!-- #post-1936 -->

			
		
		</div><!-- #content-container -->



	</div><!-- #main -->

<article id="post-1119" class="group post-container entry-content">
	<header class="entry-header">
		<h1 class="entry-title"> 12: Advanced Conversational Italian</h1>
		<p class="section-spacing">
																MWF 11-12 <a href="http://italian.berkeley.edu/courses-timeframe/2016-spring/" rel="tag">Spring 2016</a> | 6331 Dwinelle  | <b>Instructor: Mara Mauri-Jacobsen</b>							</p>

																								
																																
																																
								
																																
								
																																
								
																																
								
																								
							<p class="ls-breadth"><span class="units">

							Units: 3</span>
										</p>
	</header><!-- .entry-header -->

	<div class="entry-content-wrapper">

	
		<p>This course is designed to develop and enhance oral communication skills at an advanced level by means of conversational practice, role plays, viewing and discussion of films and documentaries, reading and discussion of critic and audience film reviews, selected film scripts, articles and short stories.</p>
<p>Weekly oral assignments, four compositions and four oral presentations spread out over the course of the semester. A considerable portion of the final grade will be based on the overall progress and participation of the student.</p>
<p>Selected readings will be made available by the instructor.</p>
<p><strong>Prerequisite:</strong> Italian 3 or consent of instructor.</p>

	</div><!-- .entry-content-wrapper -->

</article><!-- #post-1119 -->

			
		
		</div><!-- #content-container -->



	</div><!-- #main -->

	<footer id="footer"  role="contentinfo">

<article id="post-1121" class="group post-container entry-content">
	<header class="entry-header">
		<h1 class="entry-title"> 101B: Advanced Grammar, Reading, and Composition</h1>
		<p class="section-spacing">
																MWF 1-2 <a href="http://italian.berkeley.edu/courses-timeframe/2016-spring/" rel="tag">Spring 2016</a> | 250 Dwinelle  | <b>Instructor: Giuliana Perco</b>							</p>

																								
																																
																																
								
																																
								
																																
								
																																
								
																								
							<p class="ls-breadth"><span class="units">

							Units: 4</span>
										</p>
	</header><!-- .entry-header -->

	<div class="entry-content-wrapper">

	
		<p><strong>Course conducted in Italian</strong></p>
<p><strong>Required of majors</strong></p>
<p>Italian Studies 101B is a reading and writing intensive course for students who are already proficient in Italian. Its goal is to help students improve their grammar and perfect their writing and reading skills, in preparation for advanced literature courses in Italian.</p>
<p>A variety of authentic texts of a different nature, from literature, to news articles, as well as video, audio clips, and songs will be included in the materials for the course.</p>
<p><strong>Course Requirements: </strong>Three 1-hour meetings per week. Monthly quizzes, several long and short compositions, a presentation, and a final examination.</p>
<p><strong>Prerequisites: </strong>Italian Studies 4 or proficiency placement.</p>
<p>Please contact Dr. Perco if you have a question regarding placement in this course: <u><a href="mailto:gperco@berkeley.edu">gperco@berkeley.edu</a></u>.</p>
<p>&nbsp;</p>
<p>&nbsp;</p>

	</div><!-- .entry-content-wrapper -->

</article><!-- #post-1121 -->

			
		
		</div><!-- #content-container -->



	</div><!-- #main -->

</ul></div>			</nav><!-- #access -->
			
	</header><!-- #site-header -->
	
	<div id="main" class="group">

				<div class="page">
								<div id="sidebar" class="widget-area" role="complementary">
						<div class="menu-courses-sidebar-container"><ul id="menu-courses-sidebar" class="menu"><li id="menu-item-1932" class="menu-item menu-item-type-taxonomy menu-item-object-courses-timeframe menu-item-1932"><a href="http://italian.berkeley.edu/courses-timeframe/2017-fall/">Fall 2017</a></li>
<li id="menu-item-2118" class="menu-item menu-item-type-taxonomy menu-item-object-courses-timeframe menu-item-2118"><a href="http://italian.berkeley.edu/courses-timeframe/2018-spring/">Spring 2018</a></li>

<article id="post-1117" class="group post-container entry-content">
	<header class="entry-header">
		<h1 class="entry-title"> 4: Advanced Italian</h1>
		<p class="section-spacing">
																M-F 9-10 <a href="http://italian.berkeley.edu/courses-timeframe/2016-spring/" rel="tag">Spring 2016</a> | 179 Dwinelle  | <b>Instructor: Annamaria Bellezza</b>							</p>

																								
																																
																																
								
																																
								
																																
								
																																
								
																								
							<p class="ls-breadth"><span class="units">

							Units: 5</span>
					 <em>Satisfies L&S International Studies breadth requirement.</em>					</p>
	</header><!-- .entry-header -->

	<div class="entry-content-wrapper">

	
		<p><strong>Course conducted <em>entirely</em> in Italian.</strong></p>
<p>In this course students will hone their language skills by reviewing the grammar structures learned in the previous three semesters. They will learn to appreciate Italian culture through authentic materials such as articles, films, and plays. Students will continue to build on the work done in Italian 3, striving for a higher level of sophistication and fluency in writing, reading, and speaking. Readings will be more complex and will cover a wider range of topics. Conducted in Italian. Weekly written assignments, midterm, oral presentation, and a final exam.</p>
<p><strong>Required texts:</strong><br />
<em><a href="http://vistahigherlearning.com/store/ucberkeley.htm/immagina.html">Immagina, l&#8217;italiano senza confini</a></em>, with Supersite code. A Cummings, C. Frenquellucci, etc. Vista Higher Learning 2011. ISBN 978-1-60576-260-9<br />
<em>Io non ho paura. </em>Niccolò Ammaniti. Einaudi, 2011 ISBN 9788806207694</p>
<p><strong>Recommended texts:</strong><br />
<em>Webster&#8217;s New World Italian Dictionary </em>Concise edition ISBN 9780139536397</p>
<p><strong>Prerequisite:</strong> Italian 3 or placement test. Please contact Dr. Perco if you have a question regarding placement in this course: <u><a href="mailto:gperco@berkeley.edu">gperco@berkeley.edu</a></u>.</p>

	</div><!-- .entry-content-wrapper -->

</article><!-- #post-1117 -->

			
		
		</div><!-- #content-container -->



	</div><!-- #main -->

						<div class="menu-courses-sidebar-container"><ul id="menu-courses-sidebar" class="menu"><li id="menu-item-1932" class="menu-item menu-item-type-taxonomy menu-item-object-courses-timeframe menu-item-1932"><a href="http://italian.berkeley.edu/courses-timeframe/2017-fall/">Fall 2017</a></li>

<article id="post-1945" class="group post-container entry-content">
	<header class="entry-header">
		<h1 class="entry-title"> 101: Advanced Writing Workshop</h1>
		<p class="section-spacing">
																MWF 1-2 <a href="http://italian.berkeley.edu/courses-timeframe/2017-fall/" rel="tag">Fall 2017</a> | 104 Dwinelle  | <b>Instructor: Giuliana Perco</b>							</p>

																								
																																
																																
								
																																
								
																																
								
																																
								
																								
							<p class="ls-breadth"><span class="units">

							Units: 4</span>
										</p>
	</header><!-- .entry-header -->

	<div class="entry-content-wrapper">

	
		<p><strong>Taught in Italian.</strong></p>
<p><strong>Required of majors and minors</strong>.</p>
<p>The purpose of this course is to help students at an advanced level of competence in Italian strengthen and refine their writing skills, by expanding their vocabulary, and experimenting with more complex grammatical structures. Emphasis is given on refining writing skills through a process of writing, reviewing and re-writing.</p>
<p>You will be exposed to texts from a variety of different genres and writing styles (newspaper and magazine articles, essays, personal narratives, etc.) focusing on relevant topics in Italian culture and society. Grammar will be reviewed in the context of the texts and genres analyzed.</p>
<p>This course is writing intensive. You will write several different types of texts of different length and purpose: letters, film reviews, personal narratives, argumentative texts, etc.  You will also review your peers’ work and have your own work read and commented by your peers.  Re-writing will be required for most of the texts you’ll create for this class. At the end of the semester you will have created a portfolio of about 20-30 pages in Italian.</p>
<p>The course is entirely and exclusively taught in Italian and it is a pre-requisite to any 100- level course in Italian.</p>
<p><strong>Prerequisite</strong>s:  Italian Studies 4 at UCB or <a href="http://italian.berkeley.edu/undergraduate-program/language-study-and-placement/">proficiency placement.</a>  Please contact Dr. Perco if you have questions regarding placement in this course: <a href="mailto:gperco@berkeley.edu"><u>gperco@berkeley.edu</u></a>.</p>
<p><strong>Texts:</strong>  to be announced.</p>

	</div><!-- .entry-content-wrapper -->

</article><!-- #post-1945 -->

			
		
		</div><!-- #content-container -->



	</div><!-- #main -->

	<footer id="footer"  role="contentinfo">


		<div id="footer-content">
		<div id="footer-id">
			
			<div class="footer-nav">

<article id="post-1125" class="group post-container entry-content">
	<header class="entry-header">
		<h1 class="entry-title"> C203: Comparative Studies in Romance Literatures and Cultures: Histories and Theories of Narrative</h1>
		<p class="section-spacing">
																M 2-5 <a href="http://italian.berkeley.edu/courses-timeframe/2016-spring/" rel="tag">Spring 2016</a> | 6331 Dwinelle  | <b>Instructor: Albert Ascoli</b>							</p>

																								
																																
																																
								
																																
								
																																
								
																																
								
																								
							<p class="ls-breadth"><span class="units">

							Units: 4</span>
										</p>
	</header><!-- .entry-header -->

	<div class="entry-content-wrapper">

	
		<p>Cross-listed with French C203, Section 1 and Spanish C203, Section 1.</p>
<p><strong>Advanced reading knowledge of one major romance language required, readings available in the original or in English translation as needed.<br />
</strong></p>
<p><strong>Course conducted in English. </strong></p>
<p><strong> </strong>This course is an introduction to the history and theory of narrative using comparative examples from the Italian, French, Spanish and Latin traditions. The core of the seminar will be a five-week long visit (2/15-3/14) by Prof. Guido Mazzoni (University of Siena; Chair of Italian Culture 2015-16), who will present and discuss his work on the theory of the novel. Prof. Mazzoni’s visit will be preceded by three weeks in which we will read examples of classic narrative theory and of prose narrative from the earlier periods. It will be followed by six weeks taught by Prof. Ascoli and a number of guest speakers (including Barbara Spackman; Timothy Hampton; Henrike Lange; and others) who will present on additional exemplary texts as well as on other recent developments in the study of narrative. Among the topics considered will be the genre of romance; visual narratives; “extreme narrative” and anti-narrative in the novel; and so on.</p>
<p>Students are expected to attend and participate regularly. There will may be occasional in-class presentations. The principal assignment for the course is a research paper of ca. 6000 words (ca. 25 pages). Topics must be closely related to the concerns of the course although they may focus on authors and texts from the Romance tradition not directly treated in seminar. Students enrolled for two credits [see below] will not write a final essay, but will complete all other course assignments.</p>
<p><strong> Texts: TBA</strong></p>
<p><strong>*Prerequisites and Enrollment Criteria: </strong></p>
<p><strong> </strong>Graduate standing in RLL, Italian Studies, French, Spanish and Portuguese, or Comparative Literature. Others by permission of instructor (ascoli@berkeley.edu)</p>
<p>4 credit enrollment required to fulfill RLL Core Course requirement.</p>
<p>Students wishing to take the class for 2 credits (without term paper), will be accommodated: consult Prof. Ascoli (<a href="mailto:ascoli@berkeley.edu">ascoli@berkeley.edu</a>).</p>
<p>Students wishing to audit during the five-week duration of Prof. Mazzoni’s visit (2/15 through 3/14) may do so with permission of Prof. Ascoli.</p>
<p>&nbsp;</p>

	</div><!-- .entry-content-wrapper -->

</article><!-- #post-1125 -->

<article id="post-1949" class="group post-container entry-content">
	<header class="entry-header">
		<h1 class="entry-title"> 160: Cristo si è fermato a Eboli: Carlo Levi and Italy’s ‘Southern Question’</h1>
		<p class="section-spacing">
																TuTh 11-12:30 <a href="http://italian.berkeley.edu/courses-timeframe/2017-fall/" rel="tag">Fall 2017</a> | 6331 Dwinelle  | <b>Instructor: Mia Fuller</b>							</p>

																								
																																
																																
								
																																
								
																																
								
																																
								
																								
							<p class="ls-breadth"><span class="units">

							Units: 4</span>
					 <em>Satisfies L&S Historical Studies OR Social & Behavioral Sciences breadth requirement.</em>					</p>
	</header><!-- .entry-header -->

	<div class="entry-content-wrapper">

	
		<p><strong>Taught in Italian</strong></p>
<p>This course is structured along a close and contextual reading of Carlo Levi’s classic work, <em>Christ Stopped at Eboli</em> (1945) with additional texts and discussions taking into account, among others, questions of Italy’s modernity, the ‘southern Question’, Fascist Italy’s imperial war on Ethiopia, Italian emigrants to the United States, agriculture and poverty, and religion versus paganism. Students will give oral presentations, write short commentaries and essays, and write a final research paper.</p>
<p><strong>Texts:</strong></p>
<p>Carlo Levi, <em>Cristo si è fermato a Eboli.</em> Einaudi 2014. ISBN 9788806219345</p>
<p>Additional readings will be posted on bCourses.</p>
<p><strong>Prerequisites</strong>: Italian 101 or permission of instructor</p>

	</div><!-- .entry-content-wrapper -->

</article><!-- #post-1949 -->

			
		
		</div><!-- #content-container -->



	</div><!-- #main -->

<article id="post-1948" class="group post-container entry-content">
	<header class="entry-header">
		<h1 class="entry-title"> 130A: Dante&#8217;s Inferno</h1>
		<p class="section-spacing">
																MWF 3-4 <a href="http://italian.berkeley.edu/courses-timeframe/2017-fall/" rel="tag">Fall 2017</a> | 219 Dwinelle  | <b>Instructor: Steven Botterill</b>							</p>

																								
																																
																																
								
																																
								
																																
								
																																
								
																								
							<p class="ls-breadth"><span class="units">

							Units: 4</span>
					 <em>Satisfies L&S Philosophy & Values OR Arts & Literature breadth requirement.</em>					</p>
	</header><!-- .entry-header -->

	<div class="entry-content-wrapper">

	
		<p><strong>Taught in English, using a parallel-text edition of Inferno.</strong></p>
<p><strong> </strong>A close introductory reading of Dante&#8217;s <em>Inferno</em>, aimed at guiding readers through a complex and challenging poetic narrative, situating Dante and his work in their intellectual, historical, and cultural context, and discussing the questions of ethics, aesthetics, interpretation, and critical practice raised by the provocative presence of this medieval masterpiece in the early twenty-first century.</p>
<p><strong>Prerequisites:  </strong>None.</p>
<p><strong>Requirements:</strong><br />
Students will be expected to participate in class discussion and write several very short (1-2 pages) response papers in the first half of the semester; thereafter, in consultation with the instructor, they will devise an individual project on which they will write a research paper.  There will be no midterm or final exam.</p>
<p>Italian Studies majors (and intending minors) may, if they wish, count this as one of their taught-in-Italian courses, <em>on condition that all written work for the course is done in Italian</em>.</p>
<p><strong>Text: </strong>Dante Alighieri, <em>Inferno</em>, translated by Stanley Lombardo (Hackett), ISBN: 978-0872209176</p>

	</div><!-- .entry-content-wrapper -->

</article><!-- #post-1948 -->

			
		
		</div><!-- #content-container -->



	</div><!-- #main -->

	<footer id="footer"  role="contentinfo">

<li id="menu-item-1441" class="menu-item menu-item-type-post_type menu-item-object-page menu-item-1441"><a href="http://italian.berkeley.edu/undergraduate-program/">Academics</a></li>

<article id="post-1137" class="group post-container entry-content">
	<header class="entry-header">
		<h1 class="entry-title"> 260: Directed Readings in Italian Literature and Culture</h1>
		<p class="section-spacing">
																TBD <a href="http://italian.berkeley.edu/courses-timeframe/2016-spring/" rel="tag">Spring 2016</a> | Instructor's Office  | <b>Instructor: The Staff</b>							</p>

																								
																																
																																
								
																																
								
																																
								
																																
								
																								
							<p class="ls-breadth"><span class="units">

							Units: 2</span>
										</p>
	</header><!-- .entry-header -->

	<div class="entry-content-wrapper">

	
		<p>Directed readings undertaken under the direction of a faculty member of the department of Italian Studies in conjunction with an audit of a 100-series seminar. Required: one hour meeting per week with professor and assigned readings.</p>

	</div><!-- .entry-content-wrapper -->

</article><!-- #post-1137 -->

			
		
		</div><!-- #content-container -->



	</div><!-- #main -->

	<footer id="footer"  role="contentinfo">

		<div id="footer-id">

<li id="menu-item-1417" class="menu-item menu-item-type-taxonomy menu-item-object-people-category menu-item-1417"><a href="http://italian.berkeley.edu/people-category/core-faculty/">People</a></li>
<li id="menu-item-1976" class="menu-item menu-item-type-taxonomy menu-item-object-courses-timeframe menu-item-1976"><a href="http://italian.berkeley.edu/courses-timeframe/2017-fall/">Courses</a></li>
<li id="menu-item-1441" class="menu-item menu-item-type-post_type menu-item-object-page menu-item-1441"><a href="http://italian.berkeley.edu/undergraduate-program/">Academics</a></li>

        $(this).parent().attr("title",function(i,val){
            return val == alt ? "" : alt;

<article id="post-1954" class="group post-container entry-content">
	<header class="entry-header">
		<h1 class="entry-title"> 260: Directed Readings in Italian Literature and Culture</h1>
		<p class="section-spacing">
																Day/Time TBA <a href="http://italian.berkeley.edu/courses-timeframe/2017-fall/" rel="tag">Fall 2017</a> | Instructor's Office  | <b>Instructor: The Staff</b>							</p>

																								
																																
																																
								
																																
								
																																
								
																																
								
																								
							<p class="ls-breadth"><span class="units">

							Units: 2</span>
										</p>
	</header><!-- .entry-header -->

	<div class="entry-content-wrapper">

	
		<p>Directed readings undertaken under the direction of a faculty member of the department of Italian Studies in conjunction with an audit of a 100-series seminar.  Required: one hour meeting per week with professor and assigned readings.</p>

	</div><!-- .entry-content-wrapper -->

</article><!-- #post-1954 -->

			
		
		</div><!-- #content-container -->



	</div><!-- #main -->

	<footer id="footer"  role="contentinfo">


		<div id="footer-content">
		<div id="footer-id">
			
			<div class="footer-nav">
				<div class="menu-footer-menu-container"><ul id="menu-footer-menu" class="menu"><li id="menu-item-1478" class="menu-item menu-item-type-post_type menu-item-object-page menu-item-1478"><a href="http://italian.berkeley.edu/news-events/upcoming-events/">News &#038; Events</a></li>
<li id="menu-item-1417" class="menu-item menu-item-type-taxonomy menu-item-object-people-category menu-item-1417"><a href="http://italian.berkeley.edu/people-category/core-faculty/">People</a></li>
<li id="menu-item-1976" class="menu-item menu-item-type-taxonomy menu-item-object-courses-timeframe menu-item-1976"><a href="http://italian.berkeley.edu/courses-timeframe/2017-fall/">Courses</a></li>
<li id="menu-item-1441" class="menu-item menu-item-type-post_type menu-item-object-page menu-item-1441"><a href="http://italian.berkeley.edu/undergraduate-program/">Academics</a></li>
<li id="menu-item-1555" class="menu-item menu-item-type-post_type menu-item-object-page menu-item-1555"><a href="http://italian.berkeley.edu/study-abroad/">Study Abroad</a></li>

</ul></div>				</div>

<li id="menu-item-1559" class="menu-item menu-item-type-post_type menu-item-object-page menu-item-1559"><a href="http://italian.berkeley.edu/courses-for-non-ucb-students/">Courses for Non-UCB Students</a></li>
<li id="menu-item-1570" class="menu-item menu-item-type-post_type menu-item-object-page menu-item-1570"><a href="http://italian.berkeley.edu/courses-archive/">Courses Archive</a></li>
</ul></div>		</div><!-- #secondary .widget-area -->


			
				
<article id="post-1933" class="group post-container entry-content">
	<header class="entry-header">
		<h1 class="entry-title"> 1: Elementary Italian</h1>
		<p class="section-spacing">
								<b>Section 1: </b>								MW 8-10, F 9-10 <a href="http://italian.berkeley.edu/courses-timeframe/2017-fall/" rel="tag">Fall 2017</a> | 206 Dwinelle  | <b>Instructor: Chiara Cecchelli</b>							</p>

								<p class="section-spacing"><b>Section 2: </b> 								M-F 9-10 <a href="http://italian.berkeley.edu/courses-timeframe/2017-fall/" rel="tag">Fall 2017</a> | 179 Dwinelle | <b>Instructor: Michiko Arai</b>								</p>
								<p class="section-spacing"><b>Section 3: </b> 								M-F 10-11 <a href="http://italian.berkeley.edu/courses-timeframe/2017-fall/" rel="tag">Fall 2017</a> | 179 Dwinelle | <b>Instructor: Kristen Keach</b>								</p>								
								<p class="section-spacing"><b>Section 4: </b> 								M-F 11-12 <a href="http://italian.berkeley.edu/courses-timeframe/2017-fall/" rel="tag">Fall 2017</a> | 183 Dwinelle | <b>Instructor: Zachary Bekowies</b>								</p>								
								
								<p class="section-spacing five"><b>Section 5: </b> 								M-F 1-2 <a href="http://italian.berkeley.edu/courses-timeframe/2017-fall/" rel="tag">Fall 2017</a> | 130 Dwinelle | <b>Instructor: Nicole Trigg</b>								</p>								
								
																																
								
																																
								
																								
							<p class="ls-breadth"><span class="units">

							Units: 5</span>
										</p>
	</header><!-- .entry-header -->

	<div class="entry-content-wrapper">

	
		<p><strong>Course conducted entirely in Italian.</strong><br />
Italian Studies 1 is for beginners and focuses on developing basic language skills (reading, writing, speaking, and listening) in Italian. The course is taught in Italian. Italian, not English, will be spoken in class at all times; students will be exposed to authentic Italian material from films, songs, websites, and will have the opportunity to practice their listening and speaking skills on a daily basis.<br />
At the end of the semester, students will be able to use Italian to talk about themselves, their family, friends, and interests, as well as to describe present and past events in Italian and to converse with peers about their everyday life.<br />
<strong>Course Requirements:</strong> Five hours per week. Weekly quizzes, a midterm, an oral exam, final project and a final. Regular daily attendance is required.<br />
<strong>Required texts:</strong><br />
<a href="https://vistahigherlearning.com/school/ucberkeley"><em>Sentieri</em>, 2nd edition</a>, Julia M. Cozzarelli, Vista Higher Learning Publishing, 2015.<br />
<em>Please use the link above to purchase the textbook.</em></p>
<p>Webster&#8217;s New World Italian Dictionary Concise edition. ISBN 9780139536397<br />
<strong>Recommended texts:</strong><br />
English Grammar for Students of Italian, 3rd edition- S. Adorni, K Primorac. Olivia and Hill. ISBN 9780934034401<br />
<strong>Prerequisites:</strong> None. Italian 1 presumes no former study of Italian.</p>

	</div><!-- .entry-content-wrapper -->

</article><!-- #post-1933 -->

			
		
		</div><!-- #content-container -->



	</div><!-- #main -->

<li id="menu-item-1976" class="menu-item menu-item-type-taxonomy menu-item-object-courses-timeframe menu-item-1976"><a href="http://italian.berkeley.edu/courses-timeframe/2017-fall/">Courses</a></li>
<li id="menu-item-1441" class="menu-item menu-item-type-post_type menu-item-object-page menu-item-1441"><a href="http://italian.berkeley.edu/undergraduate-program/">Academics</a></li>

<article id="post-1935" class="group post-container entry-content">
	<header class="entry-header">
		<h1 class="entry-title"> 2: Elementary Italian</h1>
		<p class="section-spacing">
								<b>Section 1: </b>								M-F 10-11 <a href="http://italian.berkeley.edu/courses-timeframe/2017-fall/" rel="tag">Fall 2017</a> | 183 Dwinelle  | <b>Instructor: Mara Mauri-Jacobsen</b>							</p>

								<p class="section-spacing"><b>Section 2: </b> 								M-F 11-12 <a href="http://italian.berkeley.edu/courses-timeframe/2017-fall/" rel="tag">Fall 2017</a> | 179 Dwinelle | <b>Instructor: Brenda Rosado</b>								</p>
																																
																																
								
																																
								
																																
								
																																
								
																								
							<p class="ls-breadth"><span class="units">

							Units: 5</span>
										</p>
	</header><!-- .entry-header -->

	<div class="entry-content-wrapper">

	
		<p><strong>Course conducted <u>entirely</u> in Italian</strong></p>
<p>This course is for students who have already a basic knowledge of Italian and want to continue the study of the language. The course is taught in Italian. Italian, not English, will be spoken in class at all times, students will be exposed to authentic Italian material from films, songs, websites, and will have the opportunity to practice their listening and speaking skills on a daily basis.</p>
<p>At the end of the semester, students will be able to use Italian to talk about their life, to describe present, past and future events, to give suggestions, to discuss their choices and opportunities. Students will be able to understand short dialogues, conversations, and clips from mainstream Italian films and to express their ideas both orally and in writing on a variety of topics.</p>
<p><strong>Course Requirements:</strong>  Five hours per week.  Weekly quizzes, midterm, oral exam, final project and a final exam. Regular daily attendance is required.</p>
<p><strong>Required texts:</strong></p>
<p><a href="https://vistahigherlearning.com/school/ucberkeley"><em>Sentieri</em>, 2nd edition</a>, Julia M. Cozzarelli, Vista Higher Learning Publishing, 2015.</p>
<p><em>Webster&#8217;s New World Italian Dictionary </em>Concise edition ISBN 9780139536397</p>
<p><strong>Recommended texts:</strong></p>
<p><em>English Grammar for Students of Italian, </em>3rd edition- S. Adorni, K Primorac. Olivia and Hill. ISBN 9780934034401</p>
<p><strong>Prerequisites:</strong>  Italian 1 at UCB or <a href="http://italian.berkeley.edu/undergraduate-program/language-study-and-placement/">placement test</a>. Please contact Dr. Perco if you have questions regarding placement in this course: <a href="mailto:gperco@berkeley.edu"><u>gperco@berkeley.edu</u></a>.</p>

	</div><!-- .entry-content-wrapper -->

</article><!-- #post-1935 -->

			
		
		</div><!-- #content-container -->



	</div><!-- #main -->

<article id="post-1113" class="group post-container entry-content">
	<header class="entry-header">
		<h1 class="entry-title"> 1: Elementary Italian</h1>
		<p class="section-spacing">
								<b>Section 1: </b>								M-F 9-10 <a href="http://italian.berkeley.edu/courses-timeframe/2016-spring/" rel="tag">Spring 2016</a> | 254 Dwinelle  | <b>Instructor: Language Coordinator: Giuliana Perco</b>							</p>

								<p class="section-spacing"><b>Section 2: </b> 								M-F 10-11 <a href="http://italian.berkeley.edu/courses-timeframe/2016-spring/" rel="tag">Spring 2016</a> | 179 Dwinelle | <b>Instructor: Language Coordinator: Giuliana Perco</b>								</p>
								<p class="section-spacing"><b>Section 3: </b> 								M-F 11-12 <a href="http://italian.berkeley.edu/courses-timeframe/2016-spring/" rel="tag">Spring 2016</a> | 255 Dwinelle | <b>Instructor: Language Coordinator: Giuliana Perco</b>								</p>								
								<p class="section-spacing"><b>Section 4: </b> 								M-F 12-1 <a href="http://italian.berkeley.edu/courses-timeframe/2016-spring/" rel="tag">Spring 2016</a> | 254 Dwinelle | <b>Instructor: Language Coordinator: Giuliana Perco</b>								</p>								
								
																																
								
																																
								
																																
								
																								
							<p class="ls-breadth"><span class="units">

							Units: 5</span>
										</p>
	</header><!-- .entry-header -->

	<div class="entry-content-wrapper">

	
		<p><strong>Course conducted <em>entirely</em> in Italian</strong></p>
<p>This course is for beginners and focuses on developing basic language skills (reading, writing, speaking, and listening) in Italian. The course is taught in Italian. Italian, not English, will be spoken in class at all times; students will be exposed to authentic Italian material from films, songs, websites, and will have the opportunity to practice their listening and speaking skills on a daily basis.</p>
<p>At the end of the semester, students will be able to use Italian to talk about themselves, their family, town, friends, and interests, as well as to describe present and past events in Italian and to converse with peers about their everyday life.</p>
<p><strong>Course Requirements:</strong> Five hours per week. Weekly quizzes, a midterm, an oral exam, final project and a final.</p>
<p><strong>Required texts:</strong><br />
<a href="http://vistahigherlearning.com/store/ucberkeley.htm/sentieri-2nd-edition.html"><em>Sentieri</em>, 2nd edition</a>, Julia M. Cozzarelli, Vista Higher Learning Publishing, 2015. ISBN 978-1-62680-803-4<br />
<em>Webster&#8217;s New World Italian Dictionary </em>Concise edition ISBN 9780139536397</p>
<p>Recommended texts:<br />
<em>English Grammar for Students of Italian</em><em>, </em>3rd edition- S. Adorni, K Primorac. Olivia and Hill. ISBN 9780934034401</p>
<p><strong>Prerequisites:</strong> None. Italian 1 presumes no former study of Italian.</p>

	</div><!-- .entry-content-wrapper -->

</article><!-- #post-1113 -->

			
		
		</div><!-- #content-container -->



	</div><!-- #main -->

<li id="menu-item-1417" class="menu-item menu-item-type-taxonomy menu-item-object-people-category menu-item-1417"><a href="http://italian.berkeley.edu/people-category/core-faculty/">People</a></li>
<li id="menu-item-1976" class="menu-item menu-item-type-taxonomy menu-item-object-courses-timeframe menu-item-1976"><a href="http://italian.berkeley.edu/courses-timeframe/2017-fall/">Courses</a></li>
<li id="menu-item-1441" class="menu-item menu-item-type-post_type menu-item-object-page menu-item-1441"><a href="http://italian.berkeley.edu/undergraduate-program/">Academics</a></li>

<article id="post-1115" class="group post-container entry-content">
	<header class="entry-header">
		<h1 class="entry-title"> 2: Elementary Italian</h1>
		<p class="section-spacing">
								<b>Section 1: </b>								M-F 10-11 <a href="http://italian.berkeley.edu/courses-timeframe/2016-spring/" rel="tag">Spring 2016</a> | 130 Dwinelle  | <b>Instructor: Language Coordinator: Giuliana Perco</b>							</p>

								<p class="section-spacing"><b>Section 2: </b> 								M-F 11-12 <a href="http://italian.berkeley.edu/courses-timeframe/2016-spring/" rel="tag">Spring 2016</a> | 179 Dwinelle | <b>Instructor: Language Coordinator: Giuliana Perco</b>								</p>
								<p class="section-spacing"><b>Section 3: </b> 								M-F 12-1 <a href="http://italian.berkeley.edu/courses-timeframe/2016-spring/" rel="tag">Spring 2016</a> | 251 Dwinelle | <b>Instructor: Language Coordinator: Giuliana Perco</b>								</p>								
																																
								
																																
								
																																
								
																																
								
																								
							<p class="ls-breadth"><span class="units">

							Units: 5</span>
										</p>
	</header><!-- .entry-header -->

	<div class="entry-content-wrapper">

	
		<p><strong>Course conducted <em>entirely</em> in Italian</strong></p>
<p>This course is for students who have already a basic knowledge of Italian and want to continue the study of the language. The course is taught in Italian. Italian, not English, will be spoken in class at all times, students will be exposed to authentic Italian material from films, songs, websites, and will have the opportunity to practice their listening and speaking skills on a daily basis.</p>
<p>At the end of the semester, students will be able to use Italian to talk about their life, to describe present, past and future events, to discuss their choices and opportunities. Students will be able to understand short dialogues, conversations, and clips from mainstream Italian films and to express their ideas both orally and in writing on a variety of topics.</p>
<p><strong>Course Requirements:</strong> Five hours per week. Weekly quizzes, midterm, oral exam, final project and a final exam.</p>
<p><strong>Required texts:</strong><br />
<a href="http://vistahigherlearning.com/store/ucberkeley.htm/sentieri-2nd-edition.html"><em>Sentieri</em>, 2nd edition</a>, Julia M. Cozzarelli, Vista Higher Learning Publishing, 2015. ISBN 978-1-62680-803-4<br />
<em>Webster&#8217;s New World Italian Dictionary </em>Concise edition ISBN 9780139536397</p>
<p>Recommended texts:<br />
<em>English Grammar for Students of Italian</em><em>, </em>3rd edition- S. Adorni, K Primorac. Olivia and Hill. ISBN 9780934034401</p>
<p><strong>Prerequisites:</strong> Italian 1 or equivalent. Please contact Dr. Perco if you have a question regarding placement in this course: <u><a href="mailto:gperco@berkeley.edu">gperco@berkeley.edu</a></u>.</p>

	</div><!-- .entry-content-wrapper -->

</article><!-- #post-1115 -->

<article id="post-1980" class="group post-container entry-content">
	<header class="entry-header">
		<h1 class="entry-title"> 24: Freshman Seminar: The Mafia: History and Fiction</h1>
		<p class="section-spacing">
																Th 9-10 <a href="http://italian.berkeley.edu/courses-timeframe/2017-fall/" rel="tag">Fall 2017</a> | 6331 Dwinelle  | <b>Instructor: Mia Fuller</b>							</p>

																								
																																
																																
								
																																
								
																																
								
																																
								
																								
							<p class="ls-breadth"><span class="units">

							Units: 1</span>
										</p>
	</header><!-- .entry-header -->

	<div class="entry-content-wrapper">

	
		<p>Everyone loves the mafia &#8211; at least in films, on television, and in books. Why? And what is &#8216;the&#8217; mafia? In this seminar we will explore fictional and non-fictional explanations of the mafia as an originally unique, Italian phenomenon, and as a closed social, economic, and psychological system based on brutality and secrecy. Our materials will include a few essential readings with discussion of classic films and TV representations.</p>
<p><strong>Prerequisite: </strong> Freshman standing.</p>

	</div><!-- .entry-content-wrapper -->

</article><!-- #post-1980 -->

			
		
		</div><!-- #content-container -->



	</div><!-- #main -->

	<footer id="footer"  role="contentinfo">


		<div id="footer-content">
		<div id="footer-id">

<li id="menu-item-1417" class="menu-item menu-item-type-taxonomy menu-item-object-people-category menu-item-1417"><a href="http://italian.berkeley.edu/people-category/core-faculty/">People</a></li>
<li id="menu-item-1976" class="menu-item menu-item-type-taxonomy menu-item-object-courses-timeframe menu-item-1976"><a href="http://italian.berkeley.edu/courses-timeframe/2017-fall/">Courses</a></li>
<li id="menu-item-1441" class="menu-item menu-item-type-post_type menu-item-object-page menu-item-1441"><a href="http://italian.berkeley.edu/undergraduate-program/">Academics</a></li>
<li id="menu-item-1555" class="menu-item menu-item-type-post_type menu-item-object-page menu-item-1555"><a href="http://italian.berkeley.edu/study-abroad/">Study Abroad</a></li>

<article id="post-1951" class="group post-container entry-content">
	<header class="entry-header">
		<h1 class="entry-title"> 204: From Gramsci to Agamben: Philosophy, Politics and Italian Theory</h1>
		<p class="section-spacing">
																W 2-5 <a href="http://italian.berkeley.edu/courses-timeframe/2017-fall/" rel="tag">Fall 2017</a> | 6331 Dwinelle  | <b>Instructor: Diego Pirillo</b>							</p>

																								
																																
																																
								
																																
								
																																
								
																																
								
																								
							<p class="ls-breadth"><span class="units">

							Units: 2 or 4</span>
										</p>
	</header><!-- .entry-header -->

	<div class="entry-content-wrapper">

	
		<p>Is there an Italian Theory? What are its origins and the reasons for its popularity outside of Italy? Why do most of its protagonists, regardless of their philosophical positions, share a tense and troubled relationship with political (and religious) power? The seminar will address these and other questions and introduce students to the most important figures of modern and contemporary Italian thought. Readings will include not only Antonio Gramsci and Giorgio Agamben but a wide selection of classic authors, such as Benedetto Croce, Giovanni Gentile, Norberto Bobbio, Ernesto de Martino, Adriana Cavarero and Toni Negri. Particular attention will be given to the Italian debate on the ‘political’ (borrowing the concept from Carl Schmitt) and to the relationship between theory and politics that marked Italian philosophy from Fascism to the cold war era until today.</p>
<p>The course is taught in English with readings in English.</p>

	</div><!-- .entry-content-wrapper -->

</article><!-- #post-1951 -->

			
		
		</div><!-- #content-container -->



	</div><!-- #main -->

<article id="post-1140" class="group post-container entry-content">
	<header class="entry-header">
		<h1 class="entry-title"> 290B: Graduate Colloquium</h1>
		<p class="section-spacing">
																Th 5-8 <a href="http://italian.berkeley.edu/courses-timeframe/2016-spring/" rel="tag">Spring 2016</a> | 219 Dwinelle  | <b>Instructor: Albert Ascoli</b>							</p>

																								
																																
																																
								
																																
								
																																
								
																																
								
																								
							<p class="ls-breadth"><span class="units">

							Units: 2</span>
										</p>
	</header><!-- .entry-header -->

	<div class="entry-content-wrapper">

	
		<p><strong>Colloquium is required of first year students who take it for a grade.</strong></p>
<p><strong>Colloquium is optional for post-first-year students, who take it S/U.</strong></p>
<p>Introduction to important aspects of the professional field of Italian Studies. The course will alternate between two types of events. First, attendance at and active participation in departmental colloquia offered by visiting speakers, by UCB faculty, and by department graduate students presenting their dissertation prospectuses. Second, workshops on a variety of topics fundamental to the effective practice of professional scholarship in Italian Studies.</p>
<p><strong>Course Requirements:</strong> Students are expected to attend and participate regularly at all events. There are no writing requirements.</p>
<p><strong>Required Books:</strong> none</p>

	</div><!-- .entry-content-wrapper -->

</article><!-- #post-1140 -->

			
		
		</div><!-- #content-container -->



	</div><!-- #main -->

	<footer id="footer"  role="contentinfo">


		<div id="footer-content">
		<div id="footer-id">

<li id="menu-item-1417" class="menu-item menu-item-type-taxonomy menu-item-object-people-category menu-item-1417"><a href="http://italian.berkeley.edu/people-category/core-faculty/">People</a></li>
<li id="menu-item-1976" class="menu-item menu-item-type-taxonomy menu-item-object-courses-timeframe menu-item-1976"><a href="http://italian.berkeley.edu/courses-timeframe/2017-fall/">Courses</a></li>
<li id="menu-item-1441" class="menu-item menu-item-type-post_type menu-item-object-page menu-item-1441"><a href="http://italian.berkeley.edu/undergraduate-program/">Academics</a></li>

<article id="post-1957" class="group post-container entry-content">
	<header class="entry-header">
		<h1 class="entry-title"> 290A: Graduate Colloquium</h1>
		<p class="section-spacing">
																Th 5-8 <a href="http://italian.berkeley.edu/courses-timeframe/2017-fall/" rel="tag">Fall 2017</a> | Location TBA  | <b>Instructor: Barbara Spackman</b>							</p>

																								
																																
																																
								
																																
								
																																
								
																																
								
																								
							<p class="ls-breadth"><span class="units">

							Units: 2</span>
										</p>
	</header><!-- .entry-header -->

	<div class="entry-content-wrapper">

	
		<p><strong>Colloquium is required of first year students who take it for a grade.</strong></p>
<p><strong>Colloquium is optional for post-first-year students, who take it S/U.</strong></p>
<p>Introduction to important aspects of the professional field of Italian Studies.  The course will alternate between two types of events.  First, attendance at and active participation in departmental colloquia offered by visiting speakers, by UCB faculty, and by department graduate students presenting their dissertation prospectuses.  Second, workshops on a variety of topics fundamental to the effective practice of professional scholarship in Italian Studies.  These may include: library workshops (how to use: the graduate library, the rare book library, the department library); workshops on the research and writing of scholarly studies; workshops on the effective use of bibliographic resources, written and electronic; and so on.</p>
<p><strong> Course Requirements: </strong>Students are expected to attend and participate regularly at all events.  There are no writing requirements.</p>
<p><strong> Required Books</strong>:  to be announced.</p>
<p><strong>Recommended Activities:</strong>  physical and virtual tours of Doe/Moffitt libraries and website.</p>

	</div><!-- .entry-content-wrapper -->

</article><!-- #post-1957 -->

			
		
		</div><!-- #content-container -->



	</div><!-- #main -->

<article id="post-1122" class="group post-container entry-content">
	<header class="entry-header">
		<h1 class="entry-title"> 103: History of Italian Culture: Sicily: Facts and Fictions</h1>
		<p class="section-spacing">
																TuTh 11-12:30 <a href="http://italian.berkeley.edu/courses-timeframe/2016-spring/" rel="tag">Spring 2016</a> | 80 Barrows  | <b>Instructor: Mia Fuller</b>							</p>

																								
																																
																																
								
																																
								
																																
								
																																
								
																								
							<p class="ls-breadth"><span class="units">

							Units: 4</span>
					 <em>Satisfies L&S Social & Behaviorial Sciences OR Arts & Literature breadth requirement.</em>					</p>
	</header><!-- .entry-header -->

	<div class="entry-content-wrapper">

	
		<p><strong>Conducted in Italian.</strong></p>
<p>Sicily has a mixed reputation. Infamous as the place that produced the Mafia, it is also renowned for its beauty, food, islands, and archeological sites. Through written works and films, in this course we will examine multiple facets of Sicily’s history, starting with the 1130 foundation of the Kingdom of Sicily; and its image – as a site of danger, caricature, mystery, and ‘Otherness’ with respect to peninsular Italy.</p>
<p><strong>Course Requirements:</strong><br />
Consistent preparation, regular attendance and participation, short oral presentation, quizzes, final paper.</p>
<p><strong>Prerequisites:</strong> Consent of the instructor.</p>

	</div><!-- .entry-content-wrapper -->

</article><!-- #post-1122 -->

			
		
		</div><!-- #content-container -->



	</div><!-- #main -->

	<footer id="footer"  role="contentinfo">


		<div id="footer-content">
		<div id="footer-id">
			
			<div class="footer-nav">
				<div class="menu-footer-menu-container"><ul id="menu-footer-menu" class="menu"><li id="menu-item-1478" class="menu-item menu-item-type-post_type menu-item-object-page menu-item-1478"><a href="http://italian.berkeley.edu/news-events/upcoming-events/">News &#038; Events</a></li>
<li id="menu-item-1417" class="menu-item menu-item-type-taxonomy menu-item-object-people-category menu-item-1417"><a href="http://italian.berkeley.edu/people-category/core-faculty/">People</a></li>
<li id="menu-item-1976" class="menu-item menu-item-type-taxonomy menu-item-object-courses-timeframe menu-item-1976"><a href="http://italian.berkeley.edu/courses-timeframe/2017-fall/">Courses</a></li>
<li id="menu-item-1441" class="menu-item menu-item-type-post_type menu-item-object-page menu-item-1441"><a href="http://italian.berkeley.edu/undergraduate-program/">Academics</a></li>
<li id="menu-item-1555" class="menu-item menu-item-type-post_type menu-item-object-page menu-item-1555"><a href="http://italian.berkeley.edu/study-abroad/">Study Abroad</a></li>

<article id="post-1934" class="group post-container entry-content">
	<header class="entry-header">
		<h1 class="entry-title"> 1S: Intensive Italian for Romance Languages Speakers</h1>
		<p class="section-spacing">
																M-F 11-12 <a href="http://italian.berkeley.edu/courses-timeframe/2017-fall/" rel="tag">Fall 2017</a> | B-37 Dwinelle  | <b>Instructor: Annamaria Bellezza</b>							</p>

																								
																																
																																
								
																																
								
																																
								
																																
								
																								
							<p class="ls-breadth"><span class="units">

							Units: 6</span>
										</p>
	</header><!-- .entry-header -->

	<div class="entry-content-wrapper">

	
		<p><strong>EQUIVALENT OF ITALIAN STUDIES 1 AND 2 COMBINED</strong></p>
<p><b>For native speakers of ANY Romance language and for students with college level 4 proficiency (or higher) in a Romance language (exceptions made with departmental consent).<br />
</b></p>
<p>This course is specifically designed with the needs and strengths of native or proficient speakers of any Romance language in mind, so that the similarities between the languages can be used to promote specific learning paths. This is an intensive Italian language course, which combines TWO semesters in ONE, covering all the materials usually covered in Italian Studies 1 and 2 of Elementary Italian. The course provides an accelerated introduction to Italian, allowing students who successfully complete it to enroll in Italian 3, gaining faster access to Upper Division courses. The general objectives are to provide students with the basic tools for oral and written communication in Italian, but also to offer them the opportunity to learn about Italian culture, to reflect on intercultural differences and similarities, and to become more aware ‘multilingual subjects’ in our plurilingual society.</p>
<p><strong>Workload</strong>: This course is comprised of a master lecture class, meeting 5 times per week, and a drill/conversation section, meeting 2 times per week. Regular and continued attendance of both classes is mandatory. Due to the intensive nature of this course, students should plan to study one to two hours a day and be committed to a fast-paced learning environment.</p>
<p><strong>Conversation sections: Enroll in one.</strong><br />
101: TuTh 1-2, B-37 Dwinelle<br />
102: TuTh 2-3, B-37 Dwinelle</p>
<p><strong>Texts:</strong><br />
<a href="https://vistahigherlearning.com/school/ucberkeley"><em>Sentieri</em>, 2nd edition</a>, Julia M. Cozzarelli, Vista Higher Learning Publishing, 2015. ISBN 978-1-62680-803-4</p>
<p>An Italian dictionary for purchase to be announced by the instructor.</p>

	</div><!-- .entry-content-wrapper -->

</article><!-- #post-1934 -->

			
		
		</div><!-- #content-container -->



	</div><!-- #main -->

<li id="menu-item-1976" class="menu-item menu-item-type-taxonomy menu-item-object-courses-timeframe menu-item-1976"><a href="http://italian.berkeley.edu/courses-timeframe/2017-fall/">Courses</a></li>
<li id="menu-item-1441" class="menu-item menu-item-type-post_type menu-item-object-page menu-item-1441"><a href="http://italian.berkeley.edu/undergraduate-program/">Academics</a></li>

<article id="post-1120" class="group post-container entry-content">
	<header class="entry-header">
		<h1 class="entry-title"> 70: Introduction to Italian Cinema</h1>
		<p class="section-spacing">
																MW 11-12 <a href="http://italian.berkeley.edu/courses-timeframe/2016-spring/" rel="tag">Spring 2016</a> | 142 Dwinelle  | <b>Instructor: Noa Steimatsky</b>							</p>

																								
																																
																																
								
																																
								
																																
								
																																
								
																								
							<p class="ls-breadth"><span class="units">

							Units: 3</span>
					 <em>Satisfies L&S Arts & Literature OR Historical Studies breadth requirement.</em>					</p>
	</header><!-- .entry-header -->

	<div class="entry-content-wrapper">

	
		<p>Taught in English.</p>
<p>This course is a brief introduction to the history of Italian cinema. We will study major auteurs and genres of Italian cinema in the context of Italian culture and history from 1895 to the present. Film clips will be shown in lectures along with complete film screenings during the weekly film lab. All students must attend both the weekly lectures and screenings.</p>
<p>Texts and films to be announced.</p>
<p><strong>Prerequisites: </strong>none. No prior knowledge of Italian cinema or theory is necessary.</p>
<p>Screenings: M 2-4, 223 Dwinelle. CCN: 46954</p>
<p>Discussion Sections:<br />
Section 101: F 11-12, 54 Barrows. CCN: 46957<br />
Section 102: F 12-1, 235 Dwinelle. CCN: 46960<br />
Section 103: F 2-3, 106 Dwinelle. CCN: 46963</p>

	</div><!-- .entry-content-wrapper -->

</article><!-- #post-1120 -->

			
		
		</div><!-- #content-container -->



	</div><!-- #main -->

	<footer id="footer"  role="contentinfo">

<li id="menu-item-1441" class="menu-item menu-item-type-post_type menu-item-object-page menu-item-1441"><a href="http://italian.berkeley.edu/undergraduate-program/">Academics</a></li>

        $(this).parent().attr("title",function(i,val){
            return val == alt ? "" : alt;
