<article id="post-1943" class="group post-container entry-content">
	<header class="entry-header">
		<h1 class="entry-title"> 40: Italian Culture</h1>
		<p class="section-spacing">
																MW 2-3 <a href="http://italian.berkeley.edu/courses-timeframe/2017-fall/" rel="tag">Fall 2017</a> | 159 Mulford  | <b>Instructor: Mia Fuller</b>							</p>

																								
																																
																																
								
																																
								
																																
								
																																
								
																								
							<p class="ls-breadth"><span class="units">

							Units: 4</span>
					 <em>Satisfies L&S Arts & Literature OR Historical Studies OR Social & Behavioral Sciences breadth requirement.</em>					</p>
	</header><!-- .entry-header -->

	<div class="entry-content-wrapper">

	
		<p>This interdisciplinary course is a broad-based introduction to the culture and history of the Italian peninsula, from the Middle Ages to the present day. It offers a survey of major developments in politics, music, art, architecture, cinema, literature, and various forms of popular culture. We will encounter numerous individual artists, writers and political figures, from Dante in the 1300s through Michelangelo and Verdi to Berlusconi today, placing them and their achievements in a rich social and historical context. In describing the development of Italy as a nation-state and Italians as a people, we will trace continuities and changes from the independent city-states of the medieval period through the princely courts of the Renaissance, the foreign occupations of the seventeenth and eighteenth centuries, the nationalist movements of the 1800s, and the challenges faced by an autonomous Italy in the last century and a half, as it has experimented in turn with liberalism, colonialism, and totalitarianism, before settling down as the fractious Republic it is today.</p>
<p><strong>Texts:</strong><strong> </strong>Assigned readings will be posted on bCourses; the content of lectures and PowerPoints count as part of the course ‘text’.</p>
<p><strong>Prerequisites</strong>: None.</p>
<p><strong>Workload:</strong> Weekly participation exercises and reading assignments; 2 midterm examinations and written assignments; final examination.</p>

	</div><!-- .entry-content-wrapper -->

</article><!-- #post-1943 -->

			
		
		</div><!-- #content-container -->



	</div><!-- #main -->

<article id="post-1136" class="group post-container entry-content">
	<header class="entry-header">
		<h1 class="entry-title"> 97 or 197: Italian Language Tutor Training</h1>
		<p class="section-spacing">
																TBD <a href="http://italian.berkeley.edu/courses-timeframe/2016-spring/" rel="tag">Spring 2016</a> | 6312 Dwinelle  | <b>Instructor: Giuliana Perco</b>							</p>

																								
																																
																																
								
																																
								
																																
								
																																
								
																								
							<p class="ls-breadth"><span class="units">

							Units: 1</span>
										</p>
	</header><!-- .entry-header -->

	<div class="entry-content-wrapper">

	
		<p>The Italian language tutor training course offers a one-unit field study for Italian Majors and Minors, and for UC Berkeley students with an advanced language proficiency in Italian (equivalent to at least 4 semesters of language) interested in tutoring students studying Elementary Italian (first and second semester).</p>
<p>Tutors are responsible for 2 hours of drop-in tutoring per week, plus regular meetings with the Tutoring Mentor to discuss pedagogy and second language acquisition issues. Tutoring schedule and class meetings will be discussed with the instructor at the beginning of the semester.</p>
<p>Being a peer tutor for Italian is a great experience: you will help fellow students who have just begun to study Italian to appreciate it as much as you do; reviewing sticky grammar points for your tutees will improve your own language skills; finally, direct hands-on experience in this field will be a nice addition to your resume.</p>
<p>Peer-tutor must enroll in Italian 197 (juniors or seniors) or Italian 97 (sophomores) for 1 unit.</p>
<p>The enrollment process requires pre-approval by the course supervisor before a Course Control Number can be issued by the department to enable tutors to enroll.</p>
<ul>
<li>Your first step is to contact the supervisor and instructor of the course, Dr. Giuliana Perco (<u><a href="mailto:gperco@berkeley.edu">gperco@berkeley.edu</a></u>), and discuss with her your availability and eligibility as a tutor. Your last step will be to meet with the Undergraduate Student Services Advisor, Ms. Kathi Brosnan (6303 Dwinelle). Ms. Brosnan will review the form and will give you the course control number to enable enrollment.  Her office hours are Monday-Friday 9:30-11:30 and 1:15-4:00.</li>
</ul>

	</div><!-- .entry-content-wrapper -->

</article><!-- #post-1136 -->

			
		
		</div><!-- #content-container -->



	</div><!-- #main -->

	<footer id="footer"  role="contentinfo">

	<li id="menu-item-1456" class="menu-item menu-item-type-post_type menu-item-object-page menu-item-1456"><a href="http://italian.berkeley.edu/alumni-amici/become-a-friend/">Become a Friend</a></li>
</ul>
</li>
</ul></div>			</nav><!-- #access -->
			
	</header><!-- #site-header -->
	
	<div id="main" class="group">
			<div class="content group wideness" role="main">
				<div class="page">
								<div id="sidebar" class="widget-area" role="complementary">
						<div class="menu-courses-sidebar-container"><ul id="menu-courses-sidebar" class="menu"><li id="menu-item-1932" class="menu-item menu-item-type-taxonomy menu-item-object-courses-timeframe menu-item-1932"><a href="http://italian.berkeley.edu/courses-timeframe/2017-fall/">Fall 2017</a></li>
<li id="menu-item-2118" class="menu-item menu-item-type-taxonomy menu-item-object-courses-timeframe menu-item-2118"><a href="http://italian.berkeley.edu/courses-timeframe/2018-spring/">Spring 2018</a></li>

<article id="post-1944" class="group post-container entry-content">
	<header class="entry-header">
		<h1 class="entry-title"> 97/197: Italian Language Tutor Training</h1>
		<p class="section-spacing">
																Day/Time TBA <a href="http://italian.berkeley.edu/courses-timeframe/2017-fall/" rel="tag">Fall 2017</a> | Location TBA  | <b>Instructor: Giuliana Perco</b>							</p>

																								
																																
																																
								
																																
								
																																
								
																																
								
																								
							<p class="ls-breadth"><span class="units">

							Units: 1</span>
										</p>
	</header><!-- .entry-header -->

	<div class="entry-content-wrapper">

	
		<p>The Italian language tutor training course offers a one-unit field study for Italian Majors and Minors, and for UC Berkeley students with an advanced language proficiency in Italian (equivalent to at least 4 semesters of language instruction) who are interested in tutoring students enrolled in Elementary Italian (first and second semester).</p>
<p>Tutors are responsible for 2 hours of drop-in tutoring per week, as well as regular meetings with the instructor to discuss pedagogy and second language acquisition issues.  Tutoring schedule and class meetings will be discussed at the beginning of the semester.</p>
<p>Being a peer tutor for Italian is a great experience: you will help fellow students who have just begun to study Italian to appreciate it as much as you do; reviewing sticky grammar points for your tutees will improve your own language skills; finally, direct hands-on experience in this field will be an useful addition to your resume.<br />
Peer-tutor must enroll in Italian 197 (juniors or seniors) or Italian 97 (freshmen and sophomores) for 1 unit.</p>
<p>The enrollment process requires pre-approval before a Course Control Number can be issued by the department to enable tutors to enroll. Therefore, your first step is to contact the supervisor and instructor of the course, Dr. Giuliana Perco (<u><a href="mailto:gperco@berkeley.edu">gperco@berkeley.edu</a></u>), and discuss with her your availability and eligibility as a tutor.</p>
<p><strong>Prerequisite</strong>:  Italian Studies 4 proficiency or equivalent</p>

	</div><!-- .entry-content-wrapper -->

</article><!-- #post-1944 -->

			
		
		</div><!-- #content-container -->



	</div><!-- #main -->

						<div class="menu-courses-sidebar-container"><ul id="menu-courses-sidebar" class="menu"><li id="menu-item-1932" class="menu-item menu-item-type-taxonomy menu-item-object-courses-timeframe menu-item-1932"><a href="http://italian.berkeley.edu/courses-timeframe/2017-fall/">Fall 2017</a></li>

<article id="post-1996" class="group post-container entry-content">
	<header class="entry-header">
		<h1 class="entry-title"> History 149B: Italy in the Age of Dante (1000-1350)</h1>
		<p class="section-spacing">
																MWF 11-12 <a href="http://italian.berkeley.edu/courses-timeframe/2017-fall/" rel="tag">Fall 2017</a> | 109 Dwinelle  | <b>Instructor: Maureen Miller</b>							</p>

																								
																																
																																
								
																																
								
																																
								
																																
								
																								
							<p class="ls-breadth"><span class="units">

							Units: 4</span>
					 <em>Satisfies L&S Historical Studies OR Social & Behavioral Sciences breadth requirement.</em>					</p>
	</header><!-- .entry-header -->

	<div class="entry-content-wrapper">

	
		<p>The history of medieval Italy is one of vivid contrasts: of beauty and brutality, freedom and tyranny, piety and blasphemy. The great poet of the Inferno summons us to consider such contrasts in nearly every canto: how can such stunningly beautiful language conjure images of such horrendous violence? This course explores the world that produced Dante, Giotto, and Saint Francis. It first traces the emergence of independent city-states in northern and central Italy after the millennium, emphasizing the particular conditions and experiences that created this distinctive medieval civilization. We will then focus on the culture of these vibrant urban centers using the artifacts they produced to discover the economic, social, religious, and political tensions underpinning them.  Were the divisions and inequities of this society central to its creativity?  We will explore with particular intensity the relationship between religion and society.  Special emphasis will also be placed on analyzing material and visual sources: do they tell a different story than the written sources?  Requirements include midterm and final examinations in addition to two short essays based on primary sources.</p>

	</div><!-- .entry-content-wrapper -->

</article><!-- #post-1996 -->

			
		
		</div><!-- #content-container -->



	</div><!-- #main -->

	<footer id="footer"  role="contentinfo">

<article id="post-1939" class="group post-container entry-content">
	<header class="entry-header">
		<h1 class="entry-title"> R5A, Section 1: Miniature Worlds: Mapping the Spaces of Childhood</h1>
		<p class="section-spacing">
																TuTh 8-9:30 <a href="http://italian.berkeley.edu/courses-timeframe/2017-fall/" rel="tag">Fall 2017</a> | 206 Dwinelle  | <b>Instructor: Lauren-Claire Kelley</b>							</p>

																								
																																
																																
								
																																
								
																																
								
																																
								
																								
							<p class="ls-breadth"><span class="units">

							Units: 4</span>
										</p>
	</header><!-- .entry-header -->

	<div class="entry-content-wrapper">

	
		<p><strong>This course satisfies the first half or the &#8220;A&#8221; portion of the Reading and Composition requirement. </strong></p>
<p>This course examines representations of childhood in American, Italian, and Northern European literature. Because we were all children once, we might think that we know very well what it is like to be a child. But can we really access the world of a child — even the world of our past child-self? Starting in the late nineteenth century, this course investigates diverse constructions of the child-figure in a range of genres, including novels, film, and short stories. Our particular focus will be the mapping of childhood spaces within the text. These include spaces that child characters create for themselves, either as a refuge from or resistance to the adult world, and spaces that adult characters create for children. As we explore the narrative function of these spaces, we will also question the desires that motivate their creation. In creating spaces for children, what meanings do adult authors and characters impose on them? How does the text encourage or undermine our own attempts to construct childhood? And how do we try to make the child characters conform to a unified explanation of the text? Tracing these geographies of childhood, we will thus study the relation between these spaces and the interpretative work of the reader. We will ask how the desire to access these spaces mimics the desire to grasp the meaning of the text.</p>
<p>Throughout this course, we will practice the skills of critical reading and writing, which are fundamental preparation for all college work. This course is designed to fulfill the first half of the Reading and Composition requirement. We will learn not only how to read analytically, but also how to craft clear and persuasive arguments about literary texts. In addition to three essays, we will complete exercises in style and register, grammar, and the development of a thesis statement. Each essay will be produced through the course of the writing process, including an outline, rough drafts, and peer review. We will also complete several shorter writing assignments that focus on the skill of close reading.</p>
<p><strong>Texts </strong></p>
<p>Henry James, <em>The Turn of the Screw</em><br />
Virginia Woolf, <em>The Waves</em><br />
Elizabeth Bowen, selected short stories<br />
Vittorio De Sica, <em>Bicycle Thief</em> (film)<br />
Italo Calvino, <em>The Baron in the Trees</em><br />
Rosetta Loy, <em>The Water Door</em></p>
<p><strong>Prerequisite:</strong>  Successful completion of the UC Entry Level Writing Requirement or its equivalent.  <strong>Students may not enroll in nor attend R1B/R5B courses without completing this prerequisite.</strong></p>

	</div><!-- .entry-content-wrapper -->

</article><!-- #post-1939 -->

			
		
		</div><!-- #content-container -->



	</div><!-- #main -->

	<footer id="footer"  role="contentinfo">

<li id="menu-item-1417" class="menu-item menu-item-type-taxonomy menu-item-object-people-category menu-item-1417"><a href="http://italian.berkeley.edu/people-category/core-faculty/">People</a></li>
<li id="menu-item-1976" class="menu-item menu-item-type-taxonomy menu-item-object-courses-timeframe menu-item-1976"><a href="http://italian.berkeley.edu/courses-timeframe/2017-fall/">Courses</a></li>
<li id="menu-item-1441" class="menu-item menu-item-type-post_type menu-item-object-page menu-item-1441"><a href="http://italian.berkeley.edu/undergraduate-program/">Academics</a></li>

<article id="post-1128" class="group post-container entry-content">
	<header class="entry-header">
		<h1 class="entry-title"> 302: Practicum in College Teaching of Italian: GSI Language Training</h1>
		<p class="section-spacing">
																F 2-5 <a href="http://italian.berkeley.edu/courses-timeframe/2016-spring/" rel="tag">Spring 2016</a> | 6331 Dwinelle  | <b>Instructor: Giuliana Perco</b>							</p>

																								
																																
																																
								
																																
								
																																
								
																																
								
																								
							<p class="ls-breadth"><span class="units">

							Units: 2 or 4</span>
										</p>
	</header><!-- .entry-header -->

	<div class="entry-content-wrapper">

	
		<p>The IS 302 practicum is a continuation of IS 375 and provides further training in the teaching of Italian as a foreign language. It is required to all GSIs teaching an Italian language course. Each semester the practicum focuses on concrete didactic issues: in Spring 2016 its topic will be teaching with technology. The purpose of the practicum is to support and help GSIs to develop a repertoire of teaching techniques and to meet a variety of teaching situations.</p>
<p><strong>Prerequisites:</strong> GSI status in the Department of Italian Studies</p>

	</div><!-- .entry-content-wrapper -->

</article><!-- #post-1128 -->

			
		
		</div><!-- #content-container -->



	</div><!-- #main -->

<article id="post-1129" class="group post-container entry-content">
	<header class="entry-header">
		<h1 class="entry-title"> 303, Section 1: Practicum in the Teaching of Italian Literature, History, and Culture: Reading &#038; Composition GSI Instruction</h1>
		<p class="section-spacing">
																TuTh 8-9:30 <a href="http://italian.berkeley.edu/courses-timeframe/2016-spring/" rel="tag">Spring 2016</a> | 6323 Dwinelle  | <b>Instructor: Barbara Spackman</b>							</p>

																								
																																
																																
								
																																
								
																																
								
																																
								
																								
							<p class="ls-breadth"><span class="units">

							Units: 2 or 4</span>
										</p>
	</header><!-- .entry-header -->

	<div class="entry-content-wrapper">

	
		<p><strong>Required of Italian Studies department GSIs teaching R5A or R5B.</strong></p>
<p><strong>May be taken for 2 or 4 units</strong></p>
<p>Course may be repeated for credit. Three hours of classroom teaching per week with regular faculty supervision; attendance at faculty lectures where appropriate; routine meetings to discuss and evaluate teaching methods, including lecturing, discussion, classroom activities, grading and testing, design of syllabi and course materials. Must be taken on a <em>satisfactory/unsatisfactory</em> basis.</p>
<p><strong>Prerequisites:</strong> GSI status in the Department of Italian Studies.</p>
<p>&nbsp;</p>

	</div><!-- .entry-content-wrapper -->

</article><!-- #post-1129 -->

			
		
		</div><!-- #content-container -->



	</div><!-- #main -->

	<footer id="footer"  role="contentinfo">

<li id="menu-item-1417" class="menu-item menu-item-type-taxonomy menu-item-object-people-category menu-item-1417"><a href="http://italian.berkeley.edu/people-category/core-faculty/">People</a></li>
<li id="menu-item-1976" class="menu-item menu-item-type-taxonomy menu-item-object-courses-timeframe menu-item-1976"><a href="http://italian.berkeley.edu/courses-timeframe/2017-fall/">Courses</a></li>
<li id="menu-item-1441" class="menu-item menu-item-type-post_type menu-item-object-page menu-item-1441"><a href="http://italian.berkeley.edu/undergraduate-program/">Academics</a></li>

	 <h1><a href="http://italian.berkeley.edu">  Practicum in the Teaching of Italian Literature, History, and Culture: Italian Studies 70 GSI</a></h1>
			<nav id="main-nav" role="navigation">
				<div class="menu-header-menu-container"><ul id="menu-header-menu" class="sf-menu"><li id="menu-item-1554" class="menu-item menu-item-type-post_type menu-item-object-page menu-item-has-children menu-item-1554"><a href="http://italian.berkeley.edu/news-events/upcoming-events/">News &#038; Events</a>

<article id="post-1130" class="group post-container entry-content">
	<header class="entry-header">
		<h1 class="entry-title"> 303, Section 2: Practicum in the Teaching of Italian Literature, History, and Culture: Italian Studies 70 GSI</h1>
		<p class="section-spacing">
																MWF 8-9 <a href="http://italian.berkeley.edu/courses-timeframe/2016-spring/" rel="tag">Spring 2016</a> | 6323 Dwinelle  | <b>Instructor: Barbara Spackman</b>							</p>

																								
																																
																																
								
																																
								
																																
								
																																
								
																								
							<p class="ls-breadth"><span class="units">

							Units: 2 or 4</span>
										</p>
	</header><!-- .entry-header -->

	<div class="entry-content-wrapper">

	
		<p><strong>Required of Italian Studies department GSI teaching Italian Studies 70.</strong></p>
<p><strong>May be taken for 2 or 4 units</strong></p>
<p>Course may be repeated for credit. Three hours of classroom teaching per week with regular faculty supervision; attendance at faculty lectures where appropriate; routine meetings to discuss and evaluate teaching methods, including lecturing, discussion, classroom activities, grading and testing, design of syllabi and course materials. Must be taken on a <em>satisfactory/unsatisfactory</em> basis.</p>
<p><strong>Prerequisites:</strong> GSI status in the Department of Italian Studies.</p>

	</div><!-- .entry-content-wrapper -->

</article><!-- #post-1130 -->

			
		
		</div><!-- #content-container -->



	</div><!-- #main -->

	<footer id="footer"  role="contentinfo">


		<div id="footer-content">
		<div id="footer-id">

<li id="menu-item-1441" class="menu-item menu-item-type-post_type menu-item-object-page menu-item-1441"><a href="http://italian.berkeley.edu/undergraduate-program/">Academics</a></li>

	<li id="menu-item-1458" class="menu-item menu-item-type-post_type menu-item-object-page menu-item-1458"><a href="http://italian.berkeley.edu/alumni-amici/recent-placement/">Recent Placement</a></li>

<article id="post-1958" class="group post-container entry-content">
	<header class="entry-header">
		<h1 class="entry-title"> 302: Teaching Practicum: GSI Language Training</h1>
		<p class="section-spacing">
																F 2-5 <a href="http://italian.berkeley.edu/courses-timeframe/2017-fall/" rel="tag">Fall 2017</a> | 6331 Dwinelle  | <b>Instructor: Giuliana Perco</b>							</p>

																								
																																
																																
								
																																
								
																																
								
																																
								
																								
							<p class="ls-breadth"><span class="units">

							Units: 4</span>
										</p>
	</header><!-- .entry-header -->

	<div class="entry-content-wrapper">

	
		<p>The IS 302 practicum is a continuation of IS 375 and provides further training in the teaching of Italian as a foreign language. It is required to all GSIs teaching an Italian language course. Each semester the practicum focuses on concrete didactic issues (i.e. teaching with technology in Spring and Fall and teaching students with learning disabilities in Fall). Its purpose is to support and help GSIs to develop a repertoire of teaching techniques and to meet a variety of teaching situations.</p>
<p><strong>Prerequisites:</strong> GSI status in the Department of Italian Studies.</p>

	</div><!-- .entry-content-wrapper -->

</article><!-- #post-1958 -->

			
		
		</div><!-- #content-container -->



	</div><!-- #main -->

						<div class="menu-courses-sidebar-container"><ul id="menu-courses-sidebar" class="menu"><li id="menu-item-1932" class="menu-item menu-item-type-taxonomy menu-item-object-courses-timeframe menu-item-1932"><a href="http://italian.berkeley.edu/courses-timeframe/2017-fall/">Fall 2017</a></li>

</ul></div>		</div><!-- #secondary .widget-area -->


			
				
<article id="post-1952" class="group post-container entry-content">
	<header class="entry-header">
		<h1 class="entry-title"> 205: Proseminar: Literary Theory/Literary History</h1>
		<p class="section-spacing">
																M 2-5 <a href="http://italian.berkeley.edu/courses-timeframe/2017-fall/" rel="tag">Fall 2017</a> | 6331 Dwinelle  | <b>Instructor: Barbara Spackman</b>							</p>

																								
																																
																																
								
																																
								
																																
								
																																
								
																								
							<p class="ls-breadth"><span class="units">

							Units: 2 or 4</span>
										</p>
	</header><!-- .entry-header -->

	<div class="entry-content-wrapper">

	
		<p>The Proseminar serves as the core course for the Italian Studies graduate program, and aims to provide students with a foundation for literary study as it is practiced in the U.S.  To that end, we will read a series of foundational theoretical essays, focused on a set of key words that are themselves metonymies for major theoretical approaches. This fall, those key words will be “ideology,” “gender,” “rhetoric,” “affect,” and “animal.”  Theorists read will include Ahmed, Althusser, Barthes, Butler, Culler, De Lauretis, Derrida, Freud, Marx, Ngai, Sedgwick, Singer.    Our readings in theory will be complemented by readings in literary texts drawn from several different periods in the Italian tradition. The literary texts will offer us the occasion to test the practices of reading and methodological approaches that emerge from our discussions of theory. Authors read will include Boccaccio, Petrarca, Stampa, Franco, Verga, Foscolo, and Ortese.</p>
<p>Students will be required to give one or two in-class presentations (depending upon the number of students enrolled), and to write two short 8-10 page papers.</p>
<p>The course is required of M.A. students, and recommended for Ph.D. students.</p>

	</div><!-- .entry-content-wrapper -->

</article><!-- #post-1952 -->

			
		
		</div><!-- #content-container -->



	</div><!-- #main -->

	<footer id="footer"  role="contentinfo">


		<div id="footer-content">
		<div id="footer-id">
			
			<div class="footer-nav">

        $(this).parent().attr("title",function(i,val){
            return val == alt ? "" : alt;
        });
    });
});

<article id="post-1139" class="group post-container entry-content">
	<header class="entry-header">
		<h1 class="entry-title"> 282: Prospectus Tutorial</h1>
		<p class="section-spacing">
																TBD <a href="http://italian.berkeley.edu/courses-timeframe/2016-spring/" rel="tag">Spring 2016</a> | Instructor's Office  | <b>Instructor: The Staff</b>							</p>

																								
																																
																																
								
																																
								
																																
								
																																
								
																								
							<p class="ls-breadth"><span class="units">

							Units: 4</span>
										</p>
	</header><!-- .entry-header -->

	<div class="entry-content-wrapper">

	
		<p>Regular meetings with professor. Directed reading course leading to the production of a formal dissertation prospectus with detailed bibliography. <strong>The course is required for all Ph.D. candidates. </strong></p>
<p><strong>Required: </strong>Consent of instructor.</p>

	</div><!-- .entry-content-wrapper -->

</article><!-- #post-1139 -->

			
		
		</div><!-- #content-container -->



	</div><!-- #main -->

	<footer id="footer"  role="contentinfo">


		<div id="footer-content">
		<div id="footer-id">
			
			<div class="footer-nav">
				<div class="menu-footer-menu-container"><ul id="menu-footer-menu" class="menu"><li id="menu-item-1478" class="menu-item menu-item-type-post_type menu-item-object-page menu-item-1478"><a href="http://italian.berkeley.edu/news-events/upcoming-events/">News &#038; Events</a></li>
<li id="menu-item-1417" class="menu-item menu-item-type-taxonomy menu-item-object-people-category menu-item-1417"><a href="http://italian.berkeley.edu/people-category/core-faculty/">People</a></li>
<li id="menu-item-1976" class="menu-item menu-item-type-taxonomy menu-item-object-courses-timeframe menu-item-1976"><a href="http://italian.berkeley.edu/courses-timeframe/2017-fall/">Courses</a></li>
<li id="menu-item-1441" class="menu-item menu-item-type-post_type menu-item-object-page menu-item-1441"><a href="http://italian.berkeley.edu/undergraduate-program/">Academics</a></li>
<li id="menu-item-1555" class="menu-item menu-item-type-post_type menu-item-object-page menu-item-1555"><a href="http://italian.berkeley.edu/study-abroad/">Study Abroad</a></li>

</ul></div>				</div>

<article id="post-1956" class="group post-container entry-content">
	<header class="entry-header">
		<h1 class="entry-title"> 282: Prospectus Tutorial</h1>
		<p class="section-spacing">
																Day/Time TBA <a href="http://italian.berkeley.edu/courses-timeframe/2017-fall/" rel="tag">Fall 2017</a> | Location TBA  | <b>Instructor: The Staff</b>							</p>

																								
																																
																																
								
																																
								
																																
								
																																
								
																								
							<p class="ls-breadth"><span class="units">

							Units: 4</span>
										</p>
	</header><!-- .entry-header -->

	<div class="entry-content-wrapper">

	
		<p>Regular meetings with professor.  Directed reading course leading to the production of a formal dissertation prospectus with detailed bibliography.</p>
<p><strong>The course is required for all Ph.D. candidates.<br />
</strong></p>
<p><strong>Required:  </strong>Consent of instructor.</p>

	</div><!-- .entry-content-wrapper -->

</article><!-- #post-1956 -->

			
		
		</div><!-- #content-container -->



	</div><!-- #main -->

	<footer id="footer"  role="contentinfo">


		<div id="footer-content">
		<div id="footer-id">

<li id="menu-item-1417" class="menu-item menu-item-type-taxonomy menu-item-object-people-category menu-item-1417"><a href="http://italian.berkeley.edu/people-category/core-faculty/">People</a></li>
<li id="menu-item-1976" class="menu-item menu-item-type-taxonomy menu-item-object-courses-timeframe menu-item-1976"><a href="http://italian.berkeley.edu/courses-timeframe/2017-fall/">Courses</a></li>
<li id="menu-item-1441" class="menu-item menu-item-type-post_type menu-item-object-page menu-item-1441"><a href="http://italian.berkeley.edu/undergraduate-program/">Academics</a></li>

<article id="post-1959" class="group post-container entry-content">
	<header class="entry-header">
		<h1 class="entry-title"> 303, Section 1: Teaching Practicum: Reading and Composition GSI Instruction</h1>
		<p class="section-spacing">
																F 2-4 <a href="http://italian.berkeley.edu/courses-timeframe/2017-fall/" rel="tag">Fall 2017</a> | 6323 Dwinelle  | <b>Instructor: Barbara Spackman</b>							</p>

																								
																																
																																
								
																																
								
																																
								
																																
								
																								
							<p class="ls-breadth"><span class="units">

							Units: 2 or 4</span>
										</p>
	</header><!-- .entry-header -->

	<div class="entry-content-wrapper">

	
		<p><strong>Required of Italian Studies department GSIs teaching R5A or R5B.</strong></p>
<p><strong>May be taken for 2 or 4 units</strong></p>
<p>Course may be repeated for credit. Three hours of classroom teaching per week with regular faculty supervision; attendance at faculty lectures where appropriate; routine meetings to discuss and evaluate teaching methods, including lecturing, discussion, classroom activities, grading and testing, design of syllabi and course materials. Must be taken on a <em>satisfactory/unsatisfactory</em> basis.</p>
<p><strong>Prerequisites:</strong> GSI status in the Department of Italian Studies.</p>

	</div><!-- .entry-content-wrapper -->

</article><!-- #post-1959 -->

			
		
		</div><!-- #content-container -->



	</div><!-- #main -->

<article id="post-1118" class="group post-container entry-content">
	<header class="entry-header">
		<h1 class="entry-title"> R5B, Section 1: Reading &#038; Composition: Empathy and the Written Word</h1>
		<p class="section-spacing">
																TuTh 8-9:30 <a href="http://italian.berkeley.edu/courses-timeframe/2016-spring/" rel="tag">Spring 2016</a> | 109 Wheeler  | <b>Instructor: Toby Levers</b>							</p>

																								
																																
																																
								
																																
								
																																
								
																																
								
																								
							<p class="ls-breadth"><span class="units">

							Units: 4</span>
										</p>
	</header><!-- .entry-header -->

	<div class="entry-content-wrapper">

	
		<p><strong>All Reading and Composition courses must be taken for a letter grade in order to fulfill this requirement for the Bachelor’s Degree. This course satisfies the second half or the “B” portion of the Reading and Composition requirement.</strong></p>
<p>In this course students will work to develop their expository essay writing. Together we will read and discuss a number of texts and work on techniques for freewriting, paragraph-structuring, and editing essays about those texts. In our reading (works by Boccaccio, Machiavelli, and Svevo, to list a few) we will focus on the theme of the written word itself in various forms: how written language structures thought and reality. As we investigate this theme we will work our way to a central topic: empathy. Is our basic idea of the accessibility of other minds altered when we become habituated to reading and writing? Is the whole idea of the “other” and “alterity” re-cast and re-crafted when the written word is introduced? Examining these questions will bring us to parallels between intersubjectivity and temporality, between books and minds, between reading and thinking. Our goal will always be to explore complex ideas in literary and theoretical texts, and then write about those ideas in clear and effective prose.</p>
<p><strong>Prerequisites</strong>: Successful completion of the “A” portion of the Reading &amp; Composition requirement or its equivalent. Students may not enroll in nor attend R1B/R5B courses without completing this prerequisite.</p>

	</div><!-- .entry-content-wrapper -->

</article><!-- #post-1118 -->

			
		
		</div><!-- #content-container -->



	</div><!-- #main -->

	<footer id="footer"  role="contentinfo">

						<div class="menu-courses-sidebar-container"><ul id="menu-courses-sidebar" class="menu"><li id="menu-item-1932" class="menu-item menu-item-type-taxonomy menu-item-object-courses-timeframe menu-item-1932"><a href="http://italian.berkeley.edu/courses-timeframe/2017-fall/">Fall 2017</a></li>
<li id="menu-item-2118" class="menu-item menu-item-type-taxonomy menu-item-object-courses-timeframe menu-item-2118"><a href="http://italian.berkeley.edu/courses-timeframe/2018-spring/">Spring 2018</a></li>

<article id="post-1126" class="group post-container entry-content">
	<header class="entry-header">
		<h1 class="entry-title"> 235: Seminar in 20th Century Literature and Culture: Film and Visual Culture: Italy 1960-1975</h1>
		<p class="section-spacing">
																W 2-5 <a href="http://italian.berkeley.edu/courses-timeframe/2016-spring/" rel="tag">Spring 2016</a> | 6331 Dwinelle  | <b>Instructor: Noa Steimatsky</b>							</p>

																								
																																
																																
								
																																
								
																																
								
																																
								
																								
							<p class="ls-breadth"><span class="units">

							Units: 2 or 4</span>
										</p>
	</header><!-- .entry-header -->

	<div class="entry-content-wrapper">

	
		<p><strong>Conducted in English with readings in English.</strong></p>
<p>The seminar will explore the intensely productive, adventurous, at once anxious and delirious period in Italian cinema of the 1960s through the mid-70s. In this era the material and social transformations bound up with the economic boom, the proliferation of commodity and advertising culture in tandem with the international marketing of Italy’s luxury image, the rise of television and the “disappearance of the fireflies,” the student movements and the surge of left and right wing terrorism stimulated some of the most innovative work in world cinema. This Italian “New Wave,” distinct from its French counterpart, responded to the host of political and cultural upheavals with new visions of urban space and industrial design, heightened dramas of social and sexual mores, critical recollections of the past, and dreams of revolution. Alongside exemplary works by Antonioni, Bellocchio, Bertolucci, Fellini, Leone, Pasolini, Rosi, and the Tavianis, we will consider experiments in the poetic documentary and the radical <em>Cinegiornali</em> initiatives, the phenomenon of anthology films, and the implications of international co-productions as part of our discussion of the altered environments and demographics, the shifting values of “high” and “low,” the ideological climate and visual culture of the period defined between the sensation of <em>La dolce vita </em>and the murder of Pier Paolo Pasolini. Attendance in screenings required; all principal readings are in English.</p>
<p><strong>Prerequisites:</strong> Graduate standing; consent of instructor.</p>
<p>Screenings:<br />
M 6-9, 226 Dwinelle. CCN: 47086</p>

	</div><!-- .entry-content-wrapper -->

</article><!-- #post-1126 -->

			
		
		</div><!-- #content-container -->



	</div><!-- #main -->

						<div class="menu-courses-sidebar-container"><ul id="menu-courses-sidebar" class="menu"><li id="menu-item-1932" class="menu-item menu-item-type-taxonomy menu-item-object-courses-timeframe menu-item-1932"><a href="http://italian.berkeley.edu/courses-timeframe/2017-fall/">Fall 2017</a></li>

<article id="post-1961" class="group post-container entry-content">
	<header class="entry-header">
		<h1 class="entry-title"> 375: Seminar in Language Pedagogy: Teaching Italian in College First Year</h1>
		<p class="section-spacing">
																Th 2-5 <a href="http://italian.berkeley.edu/courses-timeframe/2017-fall/" rel="tag">Fall 2017</a> | 6331 Dwinelle  | <b>Instructor: Giuliana Perco</b>							</p>

																								
																																
																																
								
																																
								
																																
								
																																
								
																								
							<p class="ls-breadth"><span class="units">

							Units: 4</span>
										</p>
	</header><!-- .entry-header -->

	<div class="entry-content-wrapper">

	
		<p>This seminar provides instruction on the theory and practice of foreign language teaching and learning. Readings and class discussions focus on methodology, class preparation, assessment, course design and development, and teaching with technology. The course includes supervised classroom practice. During the semester we will review various theories and methodologies for teaching of Italian as a foreign language; we will also examine different pedagogical approaches and their applications in practical classroom activities.</p>
<p><strong>Course Requirements</strong>:  Three hours of seminar per week. Daily attendance of the “pilot class” during the first six weeks of the semester. Regular participation, teaching demonstrations, teaching portfolio and a final paper required. Required of all GSIs in their first semester of teaching. Must be taken on a letter grade basis.</p>
<p><strong>Prerequisite</strong>s:  GSI status in the Department of Italian Studies.</p>

	</div><!-- .entry-content-wrapper -->

</article><!-- #post-1961 -->

			
		
		</div><!-- #content-container -->



	</div><!-- #main -->

	<footer id="footer"  role="contentinfo">


		<div id="footer-content">
		<div id="footer-id">
			
			<div class="footer-nav">
				<div class="menu-footer-menu-container"><ul id="menu-footer-menu" class="menu"><li id="menu-item-1478" class="menu-item menu-item-type-post_type menu-item-object-page menu-item-1478"><a href="http://italian.berkeley.edu/news-events/upcoming-events/">News &#038; Events</a></li>
<li id="menu-item-1417" class="menu-item menu-item-type-taxonomy menu-item-object-people-category menu-item-1417"><a href="http://italian.berkeley.edu/people-category/core-faculty/">People</a></li>

</ul></div>		</div><!-- #secondary .widget-area -->


			
				
<article id="post-1867" class="group post-container entry-content">
	<header class="entry-header">
		<h1 class="entry-title"> R5B, Section 2: Session C (June 19-August 11): Stories from the Neighborhood</h1>
		<p class="section-spacing">
																TuWTh 2-4 <a href="http://italian.berkeley.edu/courses-timeframe/2017-summer/" rel="tag">Summer 2017</a> | 183 Dwinelle  | <b>Instructor: Margherita Ghetti</b>							</p>

																								
																																
																																
								
																																
								
																																
								
																																
								
																								
							<p class="ls-breadth"><span class="units">

							Units: 4</span>
										</p>
	</header><!-- .entry-header -->

	<div class="entry-content-wrapper">

	
		<p><strong>All Reading and Composition courses must be taken for a letter grade in order to fulfill this requirement for the Bachelor’s Degree. This course satisfies the second half or the “B” portion of the Reading and Composition requirement.</strong></p>
<p>A <em>good</em> neighbor may knock on your door the day you move in and greet you with a fresh-baked pie. A <em>bad</em> neighbor might spy on your household from behind the curtains. When it comes to a neighborhood, whether doors are left open or not, the border between domestic and public space is porous and far from peacefully established. A neighborhood can be a community as much as a place of social tension in which proximity only masks dissonance. Although neighbors look at the world from a same portion of a city, chances are they <em>see</em> it very differently.</p>
<p>This summer we’ll take a tour of Italy through novels of the 20<sup>th</sup> century and films that thematize the neighborhood as a space of encounter, appropriation, and exchange. Layers of history, laws, wars, gentrification, emigration, compose the stratified stories of each <em>quartiere</em> that we will explore. The coursework will stimulate reflections on a variety of themes across the architectural and social boundaries of urban, suburban and peripheral realities: political power and patriarchy, multiculturalism and racism, urbanization and nature, labor and consumption, the local and the global.</p>
<p>We’ll discuss narratives that spring from the periphery of a community or a neighborhood. We’ll explore “extreme” living conditions, as they appears in Carlo Levi’s 1946 novel <em>Christ stopped in Eboli</em>, or in the postwar Neorealist film <em>The Roof</em>  by Vittorio De Sica. In other cases, we’ll discuss radical ideological and cultural standing points that compromise the very notion of coexistence, as in Amara Lakhous’ novels’ multicultural <em>piazza</em>, or in Ettore Scola’s film <em>A Special Day</em>, set in two apartments facing each other in fascist era Rome.</p>
<p>Since this is a Reading and Composition course, our primary goal is to develop and hone our skills as active readers and analytical writers. To this end, students will be expected to thoroughly read all assigned texts, attend class regularly, participate in class discussion, and complete a variety of written assignments.</p>
<p><strong>Texts:</strong></p>
<p>J.G. Ballard, <em>High-Rise</em></p>
<p>Diane Di Prima, excerpts from <em>Recollections of My Life as a Woman</em></p>
<p>Charles Dickens, excerpts from <em>Great Expectations</em></p>
<p>Elena Ferrante, <em>My Brilliant Friend</em> or <em>The Days of Abandonment</em></p>
<p>Carlo Levi, excerpts from <em>Christ Stopped in Eboli</em></p>
<p>Amara Lakhous, <em>Dispute Over a Very Italian Piglet </em></p>
<p>Elsa Morante, excerpts from <em>Arturo’s Island</em></p>
<p>Anna Maria Ortese, short stories from <em>The Involuntary City</em></p>
<p>Ettore Scola, <em>A Special Day</em> (film)</p>
<p>Vittorio De Sica, <em>The Roof</em> (film)</p>
<p>Federico Fellini, <em>Cabiria’s Nights, The Road</em></p>
<p>Pier Paolo Pasolini, <em>Mamma Roma </em>(film)</p>
<p>David Simon, selected episodes from <em>The Wire</em></p>
<p><em> </em><strong>Prerequisites:</strong>  Successful completion of the “A” portion of the Reading &amp; Composition requirement or its equivalent.  Students may not enroll in nor attend R1B/R5B courses without completing this prerequisite.</p>

	</div><!-- .entry-content-wrapper -->

</article><!-- #post-1867 -->

			
		
		</div><!-- #content-container -->



	</div><!-- #main -->

<li id="menu-item-1417" class="menu-item menu-item-type-taxonomy menu-item-object-people-category menu-item-1417"><a href="http://italian.berkeley.edu/people-category/core-faculty/">People</a></li>
<li id="menu-item-1976" class="menu-item menu-item-type-taxonomy menu-item-object-courses-timeframe menu-item-1976"><a href="http://italian.berkeley.edu/courses-timeframe/2017-fall/">Courses</a></li>
<li id="menu-item-1441" class="menu-item menu-item-type-post_type menu-item-object-page menu-item-1441"><a href="http://italian.berkeley.edu/undergraduate-program/">Academics</a></li>

<script type="text/javascript">
jQuery(document).ready(function($){
    $(".gallery img").each(function(){
        var alt = $(this).attr("alt");
        $(this).parent().attr("title",function(i,val){
            return val == alt ? "" : alt;
        });
    });
});
</script>

<article id="post-1866" class="group post-container entry-content">
	<header class="entry-header">
		<h1 class="entry-title"> R5B, Section 1: Session C (June 19-August 11): The Mystery of the Text: Unconventional Mysteries, Unconventional Narratives</h1>
		<p class="section-spacing">
																TuWTh 12-2 <a href="http://italian.berkeley.edu/courses-timeframe/2017-summer/" rel="tag">Summer 2017</a> | 2030 VLSB  | <b>Instructor: Arthur Lei</b>							</p>

																								
																																
																																
								
																																
								
																																
								
																																
								
																								
							<p class="ls-breadth"><span class="units">

							Units: 4</span>
										</p>
	</header><!-- .entry-header -->

	<div class="entry-content-wrapper">

	
		<p><strong>All Reading &amp; Composition courses must be taken for a letter grade in order to fulfill this requirement for the Bachelor’s Degree. This course satisfies the first half or the “B” portion of the Reading and Composition requirement.</strong></p>
<p><span id="DERIVED_CLSRCH_SSR_CLASSNOTE_LONG" class="PSLONGEDITBOX">What is a story? What assumptions do we make when we read a story? In other words, what conventions, techniques, or practices of narration are there to which we have become so accustomed that they seem invisible or taken for granted? Who talks and how? When does one “talk” in a narrative? How do narratives or stories sustain an illusion of reality? What happens when we have a work of literature that challenges or subvert these conventions?</span></p>
<p>This course will investigate a diverse group of modern texts, such as Calvino’s If On A Winter&#8217;s Night a Traveler, texts which all center around or are structured by a mystery (missing persons in or misplaced manuscripts); above all, these texts also manipulate, challenge, and upend the conventions of narrative. In other words, there is the mystery in the text as well as the mystery of the text itself.</p>
<p>Narratives (Not Comprehensive):<br />
Borges, Jorge Luis, Selections from Ficciones<br />
Cortazar, Julio “The Continuity of Parks”<br />
Calvino, Italo. If On A Winter&#8217;s Night a Traveler. (ISBN-10: 0156439611)<br />
Calvino, Italo. The Non-Existent Knight<br />
Mitchell, David. Cloud Atlas (ISBN-10: 0375507256)</p>
<p>Narrative Theory Texts (Not Comprehensive):<br />
Abbott, H. Porter, Selections from The Cambridge Introduction to<br />
Narrative<br />
Bal, Mieke. Selections from Narratology<br />
Barthes, Roland. “The Death of the Author” and “The Reality Effect”<br />
Foucault, Michel. “What is an Author”<br />
Genette, Gerard. Selections from Narrative Discourse</p>
<p>Research Texts (Not Comprehensive):<br />
Booth, Wayne C. and Gregory G. Colomb. The Craft of Research, Third Edition</p>
<p><strong>Prerequisite:  Successful completion of the “A” portion of the Reading and Composition requirement or its equivalent.  Students may not enroll nor attend R1B/R5B courses without completing this prerequisite.</strong></p>

	</div><!-- .entry-content-wrapper -->

</article><!-- #post-1866 -->

			
		
		</div><!-- #content-container -->



	</div><!-- #main -->

<article id="post-1868" class="group post-container entry-content">
	<header class="entry-header">
		<h1 class="entry-title"> R5B, Section 101: Session D (July 3-August 11): &#8220;Stupendous, miserable city&#8221;: The Many Faces of Rome</h1>
		<p class="section-spacing">
																TuWTh 2-4:30 <a href="http://italian.berkeley.edu/courses-timeframe/2017-summer/" rel="tag">Summer 2017</a> | 246 Dwinelle  | <b>Instructor: Leslie Elwell</b>							</p>

																								
																																
																																
								
																																
								
																																
								
																																
								
																								
							<p class="ls-breadth"><span class="units">

							Units: 4</span>
										</p>
	</header><!-- .entry-header -->

	<div class="entry-content-wrapper">

	
		<p><strong>All Reading &amp; Composition courses must be taken for a letter grade in order to fulfill this requirement for the Bachelor’s Degree. This course satisfies the first half or the “B” portion of the Reading and Composition requirement.</strong></p>
<p><span id="DERIVED_CLSRCH_SSR_CLASSNOTE_LONG" class="PSLONGEDITBOX">This summer, we’ll take a virtual tour of Italy’s capital as seen through the eyes of natives and foreigners alike. Drawing on fiction, film, poetry, and other cultural artifacts, we’ll approach the Eternal City not only as the static setting against which stories and histories unfold, but as a dynamic protagonist in its own right. “Rome” will therefore serve as a lens through which to consider broader questions related to Italian history, cultural identity, and our conceptualization of the city itself, as both a geographical reality and a space constructed by the imagination. Some of the questions we will address are: How is the “città eterna” appropriated as simultaneously a constant and fluctuating entity, a static emblem of history and a corrupting modern metropolis at once? What does it mean to author a city and how have writers and filmmakers taken on this role? How does Rome become a character of its own, one approached with an amalgam of loving curiosity, intolerance, even indifference? What kind of modern subject walks the Roman streets and how do they interact with it?</span></p>
<p>Since this is a Reading and Composition course, our primary goal is to develop and hone our skills as active readers and analytical writers. To this end, students will be expected to thoroughly read all assigned texts, attend class regularly, participate in class discussion, and complete a variety of written assignments.</p>
<p>Texts:<br />
Corrado Augias. The Secrets of Rome: Love &amp; Death in The Eternal City.<br />
Joachim Du Bellay, Selected Poems<br />
W.H. Auden. “The Fall of Rome”<br />
Terry Eagleton. “Beginnings.”<br />
Edith Wharton. “Roman Fever”<br />
Alberto Moravia. Selected stories from More Roman Tales<br />
William Wyler, Roman Holiday<br />
Federico Fellini. Clips from Roma (1972) &amp; La dolce vita (1960)<br />
Pier Paolo Pasolini. Selection of Poems: The Weeping of the Excavator, Roman Evening, Toward the Caracalla Baths<br />
Amara Lakhous. Clash of Civilizations Over an Elevator in Piazza Vittorio<br />
Paolo Sorrentino. The Great Beauty</p>
<p><strong>Prerequisite:  Successful completion of the “A” portion of the Reading and Composition requirement or its equivalent.  Students may not enroll nor attend R1B/R5B courses without completing this prerequisite.</strong></p>

	</div><!-- .entry-content-wrapper -->

</article><!-- #post-1868 -->

			
		
		</div><!-- #content-container -->

<article id="post-1123" class="group post-container entry-content">
	<header class="entry-header">
		<h1 class="entry-title"> 112: CANCELLED: Sixteenth-Century Literature and Culture: The Italian Renaissance in Words and Images</h1>
		<p class="section-spacing">
																MWF 3-4 <a href="http://italian.berkeley.edu/courses-timeframe/2016-spring/" rel="tag">Spring 2016</a> | 206 Dwinelle  | <b>Instructor: Stanley Levers</b>							</p>

																								
																																
																																
								
																																
								
																																
								
																																
								
																								
							<p class="ls-breadth"><span class="units">

							Units: 4</span>
					 <em>Satisfies L&S Arts & Literature breadth requirement.</em>					</p>
	</header><!-- .entry-header -->

	<div class="entry-content-wrapper">

	
		<p>As of 12/23/2015, this course is CANCELLED.</p>
<p>In this course we will read several notable works from the Italian Renaissance and watch modern film adaptations of them. The course will allow students to not only become familiar with important pieces of literature and political theory, but also to investigate questions about the way modernity portrays the Renaissance, and about how film portrays literature. We will read two works by Niccolò Machiavelli, “The Mandrake Root” and “The Prince,” watching a stage version of the first and a film closely related to the themes of the second, Paolo Sorrentino’s “Il Divo.” We will then read selections from Ariosto’s <em>Orlando Furioso</em> and watch Ermanno Olmi’s “Il Mestiere delle Armi,” followed by selections from Tasso’s Gerusalemme liberata and operatic versions of its more popular episodes (“Armida” and “Tancredi and Clorinda”).</p>
<p>This course will be taught in English. Grades will be determined by active participation, three essays and a final exam.</p>
<p><strong>Prerequisites: </strong>none.</p>

	</div><!-- .entry-content-wrapper -->

</article><!-- #post-1123 -->

			
		
		</div><!-- #content-container -->



	</div><!-- #main -->

<div id="wrapper" class="hfeed">
	
<header id="site-header" class="courses wideness" role="banner">
	 <h1><a href="http://italian.berkeley.edu">  Special Topics in Interdisciplinary Italian Studies: Trionfi/Triumphs</a></h1>
			<nav id="main-nav" role="navigation">
				<div class="menu-header-menu-container"><ul id="menu-header-menu" class="sf-menu"><li id="menu-item-1554" class="menu-item menu-item-type-post_type menu-item-object-page menu-item-has-children menu-item-1554"><a href="http://italian.berkeley.edu/news-events/upcoming-events/">News &#038; Events</a>

	<li id="menu-item-1558" class="menu-item menu-item-type-post_type menu-item-object-page current_page_parent menu-item-1558"><a href="http://italian.berkeley.edu/news-events/">News</a></li>

<article id="post-1127" class="group post-container entry-content">
	<header class="entry-header">
		<h1 class="entry-title"> 248: Special Topics in Interdisciplinary Italian Studies: Trionfi/Triumphs</h1>
		<p class="section-spacing">
																Tu 2-5 <a href="http://italian.berkeley.edu/courses-timeframe/2016-spring/" rel="tag">Spring 2016</a> | 425 Doe Library  | <b>Instructor: Henrike Christiane Lange</b>							</p>

																								
																																
																																
								
																																
								
																																
								
																																
								
																								
							<p class="ls-breadth"><span class="units">

							Units: 2 or 4</span>
										</p>
	</header><!-- .entry-header -->

	<div class="entry-content-wrapper">

	
		<p><strong>Taught in English.<br />
May be taken for 2 or 4 units.<br />
</strong></p>
<p>The seminar <em>Trionfi</em>/Triumphs will examine a variety of triumphal gestures in history: Rites, processions, monuments, and iconographies from ancient Roman triumphs to the present day. Stations of this cultural history investigation include: Ancient arches and their decoration, booty and spolia, Christian medieval adaptations in rites and reliquaries, Renaissance triumphs in painting, print, and literature (Dante, Petrarch, Boccaccio), iconic imagery of triumphs (Mantegna, Dürer, Rubens), the Latino tradition of religious processions, operatic adaptations, Fascist triumphal imagery under the direction of Mussolini and Leni Riefenstahl, and other modern examples oftriumphs and reversals in contemporary Italian cinema such as in Roberto Benigni’s <em>La vita è bella</em>.</p>
<p>Depending on the students’ backgrounds, interests, and level of Italian language skills, the course will usually combine some introductory remarks with the discussion of readings and artworks. Students will contribute small presentations on a text and an artwork throughout the term, and present their seminar paper topic to the group towards the end of class.</p>
<p><strong>Prerequisites</strong>: Graduate standing or consent of instructor.</p>
<p>You should have read Petrarch’s <em>Triumphs</em> (in English or Italian) at least once in your life before the beginning of our seminar meetings.</p>
<p>The course will be taught in English with readings in English and Italian. Readings in Italian will be discussed striking for balance between the participating students’ overall knowledge of Italian and the authenticity of the original texts. This means that we will sometimes look very closely into the original Italian for textual analysis, but do so communicating in English.</p>
<p><strong>Main texts</strong>: Petrarch’s <em>Trionfi</em>, ideally in the original (Francesco Petrarca: <em>Rime, trionfi, e poesie latine</em>. Ed. F. Neri. Milan 1951) and in a trusted English translation (<em>Triumphs of Petrarch</em>. Translated by Ernest H. Wilkins. Chicago 1962). Please read the triumphs at least once in an English translation before the first day of seminar as we will discuss your first reading experience of this text. Readings will furthermore include texts by Dante, Boccaccio, secondary literature on the art historical contents (Mantegna, Dürer, Rubens), architectural studies of ancient, Renaissance, and modern arches and sculptural relief, the history of triumphs (Mary Beard: <em>The Roman Triumph</em>. Cambridge, MA, and London 2009) and their application in the arts (Margaret Ann Zaho: <em>Imago Triumphalis: The Function and Significance of Triumphal Imagery for Italian Renaissance Rulers</em>. New York et al. 2004), as well as the screenplay-format novel of <em>La vita è bella </em>(Roberto Benigni and Roberto Cerami: <em>La vita è bella</em>. Turin 1998.).</p>
<p>Pdfs of all the central readings will be made available on bCourses or as hardcopies in class</p>

	</div><!-- .entry-content-wrapper -->

</article><!-- #post-1127 -->

			
		
		</div><!-- #content-container -->



	</div><!-- #main -->

<header id="site-header" class="courses wideness" role="banner">
	 <h1><a href="http://italian.berkeley.edu">  Teaching Practicum: Italian Studies 40 GSIs</a></h1>
			<nav id="main-nav" role="navigation">
				<div class="menu-header-menu-container"><ul id="menu-header-menu" class="sf-menu"><li id="menu-item-1554" class="menu-item menu-item-type-post_type menu-item-object-page menu-item-has-children menu-item-1554"><a href="http://italian.berkeley.edu/news-events/upcoming-events/">News &#038; Events</a>
<ul class="sub-menu">

	<li id="menu-item-1538" class="menu-item menu-item-type-post_type menu-item-object-page menu-item-1538"><a href="http://italian.berkeley.edu/news-events/chair-of-italian-culture/">Chair of Italian Culture</a></li>

</li>
<li id="menu-item-1418" class="menu-item menu-item-type-taxonomy menu-item-object-people-category menu-item-has-children menu-item-1418"><a href="http://italian.berkeley.edu/people-category/core-faculty/">People</a>
<ul class="sub-menu">
	<li id="menu-item-1427" class="menu-item menu-item-type-taxonomy menu-item-object-people-category menu-item-1427"><a href="http://italian.berkeley.edu/people-category/core-faculty/">Core Faculty</a></li>
	<li id="menu-item-1430" class="menu-item menu-item-type-taxonomy menu-item-object-people-category menu-item-1430"><a href="http://italian.berkeley.edu/people-category/lecturers-and-gsis/">Lecturers and GSIs</a></li>
	<li id="menu-item-1426" class="menu-item menu-item-type-taxonomy menu-item-object-people-category menu-item-1426"><a href="http://italian.berkeley.edu/people-category/affiliated-faculty/">Affiliated Faculty</a></li>
	<li id="menu-item-1432" class="menu-item menu-item-type-taxonomy menu-item-object-people-category menu-item-1432"><a href="http://italian.berkeley.edu/people-category/visiting-faculty/">Visiting Faculty</a></li>
	<li id="menu-item-1428" class="menu-item menu-item-type-taxonomy menu-item-object-people-category menu-item-1428"><a href="http://italian.berkeley.edu/people-category/emeriti/">Emeriti</a></li>

<article id="post-1960" class="group post-container entry-content">
	<header class="entry-header">
		<h1 class="entry-title"> 303, Section 2: Teaching Practicum: Italian Studies 40 GSIs</h1>
		<p class="section-spacing">
																MWF 8-9/TBD <a href="http://italian.berkeley.edu/courses-timeframe/2017-fall/" rel="tag">Fall 2017</a> | 6315 Dwinelle  | <b>Instructor: Mia Fuller</b>							</p>

																								
																																
																																
								
																																
								
																																
								
																																
								
																								
							<p class="ls-breadth"><span class="units">

							Units: 2 or 4</span>
										</p>
	</header><!-- .entry-header -->

	<div class="entry-content-wrapper">

	
		<p><strong>Required of Italian Studies department GSI teaching Italian Studies 40.</strong></p>
<p><strong>May be taken for 2 or 4 units.</strong></p>
<p>Course may be repeated for credit. Three hours of classroom teaching per week with regular faculty supervision; attendance at faculty lectures where appropriate; routine meetings to discuss and evaluate teaching methods, including lecturing, discussion, classroom activities, grading and testing, design of syllabi and course materials. Must be taken on a <em>satisfactory/unsatisfactory</em> basis.</p>
<p><strong>Prerequisites:</strong> GSI status in the Department of Italian Studies.</p>

	</div><!-- .entry-content-wrapper -->

</article><!-- #post-1960 -->

			
		
		</div><!-- #content-container -->



	</div><!-- #main -->

	<footer id="footer"  role="contentinfo">


		<div id="footer-content">
		<div id="footer-id">

<li id="menu-item-1417" class="menu-item menu-item-type-taxonomy menu-item-object-people-category menu-item-1417"><a href="http://italian.berkeley.edu/people-category/core-faculty/">People</a></li>
<li id="menu-item-1976" class="menu-item menu-item-type-taxonomy menu-item-object-courses-timeframe menu-item-1976"><a href="http://italian.berkeley.edu/courses-timeframe/2017-fall/">Courses</a></li>
<li id="menu-item-1441" class="menu-item menu-item-type-post_type menu-item-object-page menu-item-1441"><a href="http://italian.berkeley.edu/undergraduate-program/">Academics</a></li>
<li id="menu-item-1555" class="menu-item menu-item-type-post_type menu-item-object-page menu-item-1555"><a href="http://italian.berkeley.edu/study-abroad/">Study Abroad</a></li>

<li id="menu-item-2118" class="menu-item menu-item-type-taxonomy menu-item-object-courses-timeframe menu-item-2118"><a href="http://italian.berkeley.edu/courses-timeframe/2018-spring/">Spring 2018</a></li>

<article id="post-1950" class="group post-container entry-content">
	<header class="entry-header">
		<h1 class="entry-title"> 170: Seeing Red: 1975 in Italian and World Cinema</h1>
		<p class="section-spacing">
																TuTh 3:30-5 <a href="http://italian.berkeley.edu/courses-timeframe/2017-fall/" rel="tag">Fall 2017</a> | 188 Dwinelle  | <b>Instructor: Ramsey McGlazer</b>							</p>

																								
																																
																																
								
																																
								
																																
								
																																
								
																								
							<p class="ls-breadth"><span class="units">

							Units: 4</span>
					 <em>Satisfies L&S Arts & Literature breadth requirement.</em>					</p>
	</header><!-- .entry-header -->

	<div class="entry-content-wrapper">

	
		<p><em>Cross-listed with Film 140, Section 3.</em></p>
<p>In 1975, Italy was, in one journalist’s words, “deep in crisis.” The postwar economic boom known as the <em>miracolo italiano </em>had given way to the long “Years of Lead,” marked by stagnation and foreign debt as well as by unrelenting political violence: routine kidnappings and assassinations, coups planned and exposed, neo-fascists clashing with left-wing militants. And while activists continued to work for economic justice, women’s liberation, and the end of what was already being called American empire, their revolutionary projects became increasingly difficult to sustain.</p>
<p>These desperate times called for desperate cinematic measures. So in 1975 Italian filmmakers went to new—and often unlikely—extremes. They experimented with endless-seeming long takes and scenes of mind-numbing boredom. They found new ways to frame brutal violence and to show what happens when such violence saturates everyday life. They devised incongruous and troubling generic hybrids like the “unwatchable” art film, or the comedy about the Holocaust.</p>
<p>In this course, we’ll study these and other cinematic responses to the Italian crisis. In order to look deep into—even at the risk of dwelling in—this crisis, we’ll attend closely to films made in Italy in 1975 alone. But we’ll also discuss films from elsewhere that let us situate the Italian case in a global context. We’ll ask what it means that so many of that year’s films, both in Italy and internationally, produce a sense of claustrophobia and closure, on the one hand, and cataclysm or even world-ending, on the other. How does film form relate to historical transition and social conflict? How have directors both registered and resisted states of stagnation, and how have they challenged us to imagine transformation?</p>
<p>Many of the films that we’ll consider—from documentary to dark comedy and from the exquisite to the deliberately opaque—deploy radical strategies that remain resonant and engage with debates that are still relevant to art and activism today, including debates on decolonization, race, “women’s work” or reproductive labor, the legacies of fascism, the ravages of capitalism, and the meaning of revolution.</p>
<p>We will study films by Ackerman, Antonioni, Celentano, Duras, Gerima, Guzmán, Losey, Lumet, Mills, Monicelli, Pasolini, Rocha, Sembene, Straub and Huillet, Visconti, and Wertmüller. A required course reader will include texts from the period by Berger, Federici, Fortini, Mulvey, Negri, Sontag, Truffaut, and Tronti, among others, as well as more recent critical and historical essays.</p>
<p><strong>Prerequisites:</strong>  None.</p>
<p>&nbsp;</p>

	</div><!-- .entry-content-wrapper -->

</article><!-- #post-1950 -->

						<div class="menu-courses-sidebar-container"><ul id="menu-courses-sidebar" class="menu"><li id="menu-item-1932" class="menu-item menu-item-type-taxonomy menu-item-object-courses-timeframe menu-item-1932"><a href="http://italian.berkeley.edu/courses-timeframe/2017-fall/">Fall 2017</a></li>

<article id="post-1941" class="group post-container entry-content">
	<header class="entry-header">
		<h1 class="entry-title"> R5B, Section 1: Missing Revolutions in Italian Modernity</h1>
		<p class="section-spacing">
																TuTh 8-9:30 <a href="http://italian.berkeley.edu/courses-timeframe/2017-fall/" rel="tag">Fall 2017</a> | 130 Dwinelle  | <b>Instructor: Ramsey McGlazer</b>							</p>

																								
																																
																																
								
																																
								
																																
								
																																
								
																								
							<p class="ls-breadth"><span class="units">

							Units: 4</span>
										</p>
	</header><!-- .entry-header -->

	<div class="entry-content-wrapper">

	
		<p><strong>This course satisfies the second half or the &#8220;B&#8221; portion of the Reading and Composition requirement. </strong></p>
<p>This course is about revolutions that might have taken place but didn’t, or that almost were but weren’t, in Italy from the Napoleonic era to the early twenty-first century. The (non-)events known as <em>rivoluzioni mancate</em>, or missing revolutions, occupy a privileged place in many accounts of Italian history and culture, including accounts of national unification, fascism and its aftermath, industrialization, and decolonization. As we consider the importance and implications of such missing revolutions, we’ll also attend to the various meanings both of “revolution” and of “missing.” We’ll ask, for instance, not only what it means to say that a revolution has been missed, like an appointment or a deadline, but also what happens when we come to miss moments of revolutionary energy—because this energy seems to have gone missing, like a lost dog, or to have become a thing of the past.</p>
<p>Poetry has long been defined as the kind of writing that both preserves and prefigures still unrealized possibilities. (According to Aristotle, “the historian relates what happened, the poet what might happen.”) We will therefore return repeatedly to poets’ attempts to imagine revolution in the Italian context, even while we also consider the work of filmmakers, novelists, essayists, and critics. We’ll study works by Antonioni, Bellocchio, Berger, Bertolucci, Fortini, Foscolo, Gramsci, Pasolini, Rosselli, Rossellini, and Sontag, among others.</p>
<p>This is a writing-intensive course, which means that, even as we locate and learn to value unrealized potentials in literature and cinema, we will seek to realize our own potential as writers through frequent writing assignments and focused revision.</p>
<p><strong>Texts:</strong>  to be announced.</p>
<p><strong>Prerequisite:</strong>  Successful completion of the “A” portion of the Reading &amp; Composition requirement or its equivalent.  <strong>Students may not enroll in nor attend R1B/R5B courses without completing this prerequisite.</strong></p>
<p>&nbsp;</p>
<p><strong> </strong></p>
<p>&nbsp;</p>

	</div><!-- .entry-content-wrapper -->

</article><!-- #post-1941 -->

			
		
		</div><!-- #content-container -->



	</div><!-- #main -->

<article id="post-1946" class="group post-container entry-content">
	<header class="entry-header">
		<h1 class="entry-title"> 117: Twentieth- and Twenty-First Century Literature: Poetry</h1>
		<p class="section-spacing">
																MWF 12-1 <a href="http://italian.berkeley.edu/courses-timeframe/2017-fall/" rel="tag">Fall 2017</a> | 6331 Dwinelle  | <b>Instructor: Steven Botterill</b>							</p>

																								
																																
																																
								
																																
								
																																
								
																																
								
																								
							<p class="ls-breadth"><span class="units">

							Units: 4</span>
					 <em>Satisfies L&S Arts & Literature breadth requirement.</em>					</p>
	</header><!-- .entry-header -->

	<div class="entry-content-wrapper">

	
		<p><strong>Taught in Italian.</strong></p>
<p>Study of the main trends in the fiction, poetry, prose and theatre of the 20<sup>th</sup>&#8211; and 21<sup>st</sup>-century.</p>
<p>A detailed description is forthcoming.</p>
<p><strong>Texts:</strong>  to be announced.</p>
<p><strong>Prerequisite:</strong>  Italian 101(Advanced Writing Workshop) or permission of the instructor.</p>

	</div><!-- .entry-content-wrapper -->

</article><!-- #post-1946 -->

			
		
		</div><!-- #content-container -->



	</div><!-- #main -->

	<footer id="footer"  role="contentinfo">


		<div id="footer-content">
		<div id="footer-id">
			
			<div class="footer-nav">
				<div class="menu-footer-menu-container"><ul id="menu-footer-menu" class="menu"><li id="menu-item-1478" class="menu-item menu-item-type-post_type menu-item-object-page menu-item-1478"><a href="http://italian.berkeley.edu/news-events/upcoming-events/">News &#038; Events</a></li>
<li id="menu-item-1417" class="menu-item menu-item-type-taxonomy menu-item-object-people-category menu-item-1417"><a href="http://italian.berkeley.edu/people-category/core-faculty/">People</a></li>
<li id="menu-item-1976" class="menu-item menu-item-type-taxonomy menu-item-object-courses-timeframe menu-item-1976"><a href="http://italian.berkeley.edu/courses-timeframe/2017-fall/">Courses</a></li>
<li id="menu-item-1441" class="menu-item menu-item-type-post_type menu-item-object-page menu-item-1441"><a href="http://italian.berkeley.edu/undergraduate-program/">Academics</a></li>
<li id="menu-item-1555" class="menu-item menu-item-type-post_type menu-item-object-page menu-item-1555"><a href="http://italian.berkeley.edu/study-abroad/">Study Abroad</a></li>

</ul></div>				</div>

<article id="post-1124" class="group post-container entry-content">
	<header class="entry-header">
		<h1 class="entry-title"> 117: Twentieth and Twenty-First Century Literature: &#8220;Ma non è una cosa seria!” Le commedie del ventennio nero</h1>
		<p class="section-spacing">
																TuTh 3:30-5 <a href="http://italian.berkeley.edu/courses-timeframe/2016-spring/" rel="tag">Spring 2016</a> | 250 Dwinelle  | <b>Instructor: Avy Valladares</b>							</p>

																								
																																
																																
								
																																
								
																																
								
																																
								
																								
							<p class="ls-breadth"><span class="units">

							Units: 4</span>
					 <em>Satisfies L&S Arts & Literature breadth requirement.</em>					</p>
	</header><!-- .entry-header -->

	<div class="entry-content-wrapper">

	
		<p>Il periodo fascista è spesso chiamato ‘il ventennio nero,’ come se fosse un incubo nella memoria nazionale, un incubo che comunque è servito (e serve ancora) come punto di partenza per l’articolazione del sogno risorgimentale/partigiano di una ‘nuova Italia.’ Perciò non ci dovrebbe sorprendere che gli studi sul periodo si focalizzino spesso sugli eventi più tragici, sulle stragi, le leggi razziali, la guerra, eccetera.</p>
<p>In questo corso sul periodo fascista, analizzeremo testi e film che seguono invece una vena comica ed ironica, come i film di Camerini e Malasomma, e proveremo a leggere le tensioni sociali del periodo fascista attraverso opere che a prima vista sembrano non impegnati politicamente.</p>
<p>Il corso sarà condotto in italiano, con letture in italiano ed in inglese.</p>
<p><strong>Course requirements:</strong> Durante il semestre, gli studenti dovranno scrivere brevi saggi, fare 1-2 presentazioni, e consegnare un progetto finale.</p>
<p><strong>Texts:</strong> Forthcoming.</p>
<p><strong>Prerequisites:</strong> Italian 101A or B or consent of instructor</p>

	</div><!-- .entry-content-wrapper -->

</article><!-- #post-1124 -->

			
		
		</div><!-- #content-container -->



	</div><!-- #main -->
