<article id="post-1434" class="group post-container entry-content">
	
				
	<header class="entry-header">
		<h1 class="entry-title">Undergraduate Program</h1>
	</header><!-- .entry-header -->

	<div class="entry-content-wrapper">
		<p>Italian Studies at Berkeley is an interdisciplinary enterprise. You will find courses in Italian language, literature, history, cultural studies, film, and folklore offered by the Department, both in Italian and in English. You will also discover that courses with significant Italian content are often taught in other departments and programs, including History of Art, Music, Comparative Literature, Film Studies, Anthropology, Political Science, History, and Medieval Studies. If you’re thinking of a major in Italian Studies, contact the Undergraduate Student Affairs Officer as early as possible, in order to plan an individualized course of study.</p>
<p>If you have a strong interest in things Italian but do not yet know the language, we offer a range of general education courses, both upper and lower division, including offerings that fulfill breadth requirements in Arts and Literature, Historical Studies, Philosophy and Values, and Social and Behavioral Sciences. The Department also offers reading and composition (R &amp; C) courses.</p>
<p>If you already have a primary major, but would like to make good use of those credits earned on the EAP program in Italy or of upper division work done in Italian Studies here at Berkeley, explore the possibility of a minor or a double major in Italian Studies. Consult our pages about <a href="http://italian.berkeley.edu/undergraduate-program/majors-and-minors/">majors</a>, <a href="http://italian.berkeley.edu/undergraduate-program/majors-and-minors/#minor">minors</a>, and <a href="http://italian.berkeley.edu/undergraduate-program/double-majors/">double majors</a>.</p>
<p>Always wanted to learn Italian, but just couldn’t fit in into your schedule? Check out the opportunities for summer study both here at Berkeley and abroad in Florence. In addition, the EAP offers academic year programs in Bologna, Milan, and Rome.</p>
<p>If you’re just getting started in the study of the Italian language, or are interested in transferring from another college or university, you can get more information on this website or by speaking to the undergraduate adviser.</p>
	</div><!-- .entry-content-wrapper -->
</article><!-- #post-1434 -->

										</div>
			</div><!-- #content -->



	</div><!-- #main -->

<li id="menu-item-1417" class="menu-item menu-item-type-taxonomy menu-item-object-people-category menu-item-1417"><a href="http://italian.berkeley.edu/people-category/core-faculty/">People</a></li>

<li id="menu-item-1446" class="menu-item menu-item-type-post_type menu-item-object-page menu-item-1446"><a href="http://italian.berkeley.edu/undergraduate-program/language-study-and-placement/">Language Study and Placement</a></li>
<li id="menu-item-1572" class="menu-item menu-item-type-post_type menu-item-object-page menu-item-1572"><a href="http://italian.berkeley.edu/undergraduate-program/language-study-and-placement/peer-tutoring/">Peer Tutoring</a></li>
<li id="menu-item-1445" class="menu-item menu-item-type-post_type menu-item-object-page current-menu-item page_item page-item-83 current_page_item menu-item-1445"><a href="http://italian.berkeley.edu/undergraduate-program/awards-and-scholarships/">Awards and Scholarships</a></li>

<li id="menu-item-1553" class="menu-item menu-item-type-post_type menu-item-object-page menu-item-1553"><a href="http://italian.berkeley.edu/undergraduate-program/undergraduate-student-learning-initiative/">Undergraduate Student Learning Initiative</a></li>

<article id="post-83" class="group post-container entry-content">
	
				
	<header class="entry-header">
		<h1 class="entry-title">Awards and Scholarships</h1>
	</header><!-- .entry-header -->

	<div class="entry-content-wrapper">
		<ul>
<li><a href="#biasin">Gian Paolo Biasin Memorial Travel Scholarship</a> (departmental award)</li>
<li>Departmental Citation &#8211; for outstanding achievement by a graduating senior (campus-wide)</li>
<li><a href="http://www.ilcenacolosf.org/annualawardshonors/renzoturcoscholarships.html">The Renzo Turco Scholarship for Italian Language Studies</a> (extramural)</li>
</ul>
<p>&nbsp;</p>
<p id="Biasin">The Gian-Paolo Biasin Memorial Travel Prize:</p>
<p>The Department of Italian Studies is pleased to announce its annual competition for the Gian-Paolo <span class="m_-8759741856214119588gmail-m_-7080742862283215090gmail-il">Biasin</span> Memorial Travel Prize. This year it consists of an award of $2000, to be used to fund a recent Berkeley graduate&#8217;s travel to Italy for further study, either in the summer of 2017 or for all or part of the academic year 2017-18.  All current seniors who intend to graduate in Spring 2017 are eligible to apply, as are those who graduated in Summer or Fall 2016. Applicants must have achieved passing grades in <i>at least three courses</i> taken in the Department of Italian Studies, <i>at least one of which must have been taught in Italian</i>. (Courses taken through the University of California Education Abroad Program at its sites in Italy may be counted for this purpose.) Other things being equal, those who majored or minored in Italian Studies will be given preference. Applicants should e-mail a two pages description of their travel and study plans, along with the name of at least one faculty member or GSI who is familiar with their work — please note that <i>only the name</i> is required; actual letters will be solicited by the Department if needed.</p>
<div> The Biasin Prize was endowed by Professor Biasin&#8217;s family, his colleagues at Berkeley and elsewhere, and his many friends in both Italy and North America, after his sadly premature death in 1998.</div>
<p>&nbsp;</p>
<p><b>Send your submission by Thursday April 13, 2017  to Professor Diego Pirillo, Undergraduate Faculty Advisor: <a href="mailto:dpirillo@berkeley.edu" target="_blank">dpirillo@berkeley.edu</a></b></p>
	</div><!-- .entry-content-wrapper -->
</article><!-- #post-83 -->

										</div>
			</div><!-- #content -->

<article id="post-228" class="group post-container entry-content">
	
				
	<header class="entry-header">
		<h1 class="entry-title">Double Majors</h1>
	</header><!-- .entry-header -->

	<div class="entry-content-wrapper">
		<p><em>Did you know?</em></p>
<p>Students entering with Advanced Placement, enrichment courses taken at community colleges while in high school or both are in a perfect position to work on a double major while attending UC Berkeley. Units awarded that fulfill University requirements do not have to be counted towards the 120-130 unit maximum for the Bachelor’s Degree allowing students to remain at Berkeley for 8 semesters while acquiring two majors.</p>
<p>Transfer students who have completed the equivalent of Italian 1-4 before admission need only complete 32 units of upper-division coursework in Italian Studies to earn a major. Students with native or extensive academic exposure to Italian may, with language proficiency screening by our Italian language program coordinator, find that they can be placed at a higher level of language study constituting a waiver of lower-level Italian courses allowing for fewer courses to be taken for the major with the possibility of acquiring a first or second major.</p>
<p>Up to two courses can be counted for credit between two major programs at Berkeley depending how closely related the major requirements which are, in effect, two courses counting as four, making it easier to double major. There are also several majors at UC Berkeley that require 4 semesters of lower-division language that may also be applied to lower-division language requirements for Italian Studies, e.g. Political Economy, Peace and Conflicts Studies, and so on. Think 4 courses applied to 2 sets of lower-division requirements giving you a way to make double majoring work for you.</p>
<p><em>Why Two Majors?</em></p>
<p>Berkeley is a unique learning environment with a diversity of majors, curriculum, research, and study abroad opportunities. Our double majors study in fields as far ranging as the biological sciences, history of art, mathematics, business, history, and comparative literature. It may surprise some but many of our double majors pursue pre-med requirements and as biological science majors, are looking for a balance between fulfilling career goals and feeding their intellectual and personal interests in the study of the language and culture of one of the oldest and most fascinating countries in Western history.</p>
<p><em>Have we given you something to think about?</em></p>
<p>Early planning is the key. Your next step is to see our staff advisor!</p>
<p><em>Who to Talk to:</em></p>
<p><a href="http://italian.berkeley.edu/people/526-2/">Amanda Minafo</a>,Undergraduate Student Services Advisor</p>
	</div><!-- .entry-content-wrapper -->
</article><!-- #post-228 -->

										</div>
			</div><!-- #content -->

<article id="post-75" class="group post-container entry-content">
	
				
	<header class="entry-header">
		<h1 class="entry-title">Language Study and Placement</h1>
	</header><!-- .entry-header -->

	<div class="entry-content-wrapper">
		<p>The Department of Italian Studies offers language instruction at all levels, from beginning through advanced. Beginning courses emphasize oral proficiency and communication in real-life situations, as well as reading and writing skills. Materials are closely related to contemporary Italian culture and society. Advanced courses emphasize all aspects of language ability, from conversation to literary analysis.</p>
<p>If you are just beginning to study Italian, then Italian 1 is the place for you.</p>
<p>If you had some previous coursework in Italian at another college, are a heritage speaker, or have learned Italian through travel or independent study, you should take our placement test, which is offered during the first week of each semester.</p>
<p><strong>IMPORTANT: The Italian placement test for Spring 2018 is scheduled for Tuesday, January 16, 8:30-11:00am, in 6331 Dwinelle.  You <em>must</em> pre-register for the placement test <a href="http://doodle.com/poll/mnpnikenvgi52cfd">at this link</a> by January 14, 2018.</strong></p>
<p>If you have additional or specific questions about your Italian language placement, you can contact <a href="mailto:gperco@berkeley.edu">Dr. Giuliana Perco</a>, the coordinator of the language program.</p>
<p>&nbsp;</p>
<p>&nbsp;</p>
<p>&nbsp;</p>
	</div><!-- .entry-content-wrapper -->
</article><!-- #post-75 -->

										</div>
			</div><!-- #content -->



	</div><!-- #main -->

<li id="menu-item-1417" class="menu-item menu-item-type-taxonomy menu-item-object-people-category menu-item-1417"><a href="http://italian.berkeley.edu/people-category/core-faculty/">People</a></li>
<li id="menu-item-1976" class="menu-item menu-item-type-taxonomy menu-item-object-courses-timeframe menu-item-1976"><a href="http://italian.berkeley.edu/courses-timeframe/2017-fall/">Courses</a></li>
<li id="menu-item-1441" class="menu-item menu-item-type-post_type menu-item-object-page current-page-ancestor menu-item-1441"><a href="http://italian.berkeley.edu/undergraduate-program/">Academics</a></li>

<article id="post-1258" class="group post-container entry-content">
	
				
	<header class="entry-header">
		<h1 class="entry-title">Peer Tutoring</h1>
	</header><!-- .entry-header -->

	<div class="entry-content-wrapper">
		<div id="attachment_1915" style="width: 310px" class="wp-caption alignright"><img class="size-medium wp-image-1915" src="http://italian.berkeley.edu/wp-content/uploads/2016/02/Peer-Tutors-Sp17-300x225.jpg" alt="" width="300" height="225" srcset="http://italian.berkeley.edu/wp-content/uploads/2016/02/Peer-Tutors-Sp17-300x225.jpg 300w, http://italian.berkeley.edu/wp-content/uploads/2016/02/Peer-Tutors-Sp17-768x576.jpg 768w, http://italian.berkeley.edu/wp-content/uploads/2016/02/Peer-Tutors-Sp17-1024x768.jpg 1024w, http://italian.berkeley.edu/wp-content/uploads/2016/02/Peer-Tutors-Sp17.jpg 1600w" sizes="(max-width: 300px) 100vw, 300px" /><p class="wp-caption-text">Spring 2017 Peer Tutors: (L-R) Garrett, Jasmine, Simonetta, Gardenia, Alison, and Sabrina</p></div>
<p>Free Italian language peer tutoring is available for students of Italian 1, 1S, 2, 3, and 4.</p>
<p>The service is provided by the Italian Studies Department, but it is possible exclusively thanks to the generosity and availability of our tutors.</p>
<p>All tutoring sessions take place in B-34 Dwinelle Hall (B level) starting Monday, February 6.</p>
<p><strong>Mondays, 3-6pm:</strong> Italian 1, 1S, and 2.<br />
<strong>Tuesdays, 3-6pm:</strong> Italian 1, 1S, and 2.<br />
<strong>Wednesdays, 2-6pm:</strong> Italian 1, 1S, 2, 3, and 4.<br />
<strong>Thursdays, 2-6pm:</strong> Italian 1, 1S, and 2.<br />
+ <strong>Thursdays, 3-6pm:</strong> Italian 3 and 4.</p>
<p>Are you interested in becoming a peer tutor? Contact the Italian language program coordinator <a href="mailto:gperco@berkeley.edu">Dr. Giuliana Perco</a>.</p>
<p>The Italian Studies peer tutors are enrolled in Italian Studies 97 (sophomores) and Italian Studies 197 (for juniors and seniors) &#8212; Italian Language Tutor Training. Read more about the course <a href="http://italian.berkeley.edu/courses/italian-language-tutor-training-3/">here</a>.</p>
	</div><!-- .entry-content-wrapper -->
</article><!-- #post-1258 -->

<article id="post-71" class="group post-container entry-content">
	
				
	<header class="entry-header">
		<h1 class="entry-title">Majors and Minors</h1>
	</header><!-- .entry-header -->

	<div class="entry-content-wrapper">
		<h2 style="text-align: center;">UNDERGRADUATE MAJOR REQUIREMENTS (52 UNITS)</h2>
<p><strong>Lower Division Language (20 units):</strong></p>
<ul>
<li>Italian Studies 1, 2, 3 and 4, Elementary/Intermediate/Advanced Italian or their equivalent in linguistic proficiency.</li>
</ul>
<p><strong>Upper-Division (32 units):</strong></p>
<ul>
<li><strong>Language:</strong> Italian Studies 101, <em>Advanced Writing Workshop (4 units) </em><strong>and </strong>Italian 102, <em>Italian Through the Arts (4 units)</em></li>
</ul>
<ul>
<li><strong>Introduction to Italian Culture and Literature:</strong> Italian Studies 105, <em>History of Italian Culture (4 units)</em><em><br />
</em></li>
</ul>
<ul>
<li><strong>Electives:</strong> chosen from Italian literature, cultural studies, history, and film. See elective selections below <em>(20 units/5 courses)</em>.</li>
</ul>
<p><strong>Electives offered by Italian Studies (some in Italian, others in English):</strong> 102*, 105*, 109, 110, 112, 115, 117, 120, 130A, 130B, 160, 163, 170, 175</p>
<p>*Once the Italian Studies 102 or 105 requirement is fulfilled, 102 and/or 105 can be repeated for elective credit with Faculty Advisor approval, if the content is sufficiently different.</p>
<p><strong>Elective selections in affiliated departments (in English):</strong> Art and History of Art 145, 160, 161,162; History 106A, 106B, 149, C157</p>
<p>Up to 8 units or 2 courses with primary readings and discussion in English may be counted toward the total major unit requirement offered in the Italian Studies department and departments such as History of Art, History, and occasionally, Medieval Studies or Music. Courses in other departments may be taken with advance permission of the Faculty Advisor.</p>
<p><strong>Education Abroad: Up to 12 units/3 courses may count toward upper-division </strong><strong>requirements with Faculty Advisor approval.</strong> At least 12 units must be taken in residence. All courses for the major must be taken on a lettergrade basis. A grade point average of 2.0 must be maintained in the major and overall.<br />
<a name="minor"></a></p>
<h2 style="text-align: center;">UNDERGRADUATE MINOR REQUIREMENTS (40 units)</h2>
<p><strong>Lower-Division (20 units):</strong></p>
<ul>
<li>Italian language courses to include Italian Studies 1, 2, 3 and 4, <em>Elementary/Intermediate/Advanced Italian</em> or their equivalent in linguistic proficiency.</li>
</ul>
<p><strong>Upper-Division (20 units):</strong></p>
<ul>
<li><strong>Language:</strong> Italian Studies 101, <em>Advanced Writing Workshop</em> <em>(4 units)</em></li>
</ul>
<ul>
<li><strong>Introduction to Italian Culture and Literature: </strong>Italian Studies 105, <em>History of Italian Culture (4 units)</em></li>
</ul>
<ul>
<li><strong>Electives:</strong> 3 courses <em>(or 12 units)</em></li>
</ul>
<p><strong>Electives offered by Italian Studies (some in Italian, others in English):</strong> 102, 105*, 109, 110, 112, 115, 117, 120, 130A, 130B, 160, 163, 170, 175</p>
<p>*Once the Italian Studies 105 requirement is fulfilled, 105 can be repeated for elective credit with Faculty Advisor approval, if the content is sufficiently different.</p>
<p><strong>Elective selections in affiliated departments (in English):</strong> Art and History of Art 145, 160, 161,162; History 106A, 106B, 149, C157</p>
<p>At least 12 units must be taken in residence. One course (4 units) with primary readings and discussion in English may be counted toward the minor unit requirement. As noted, such courses may be taken in other departments with advance permission of the Faculty Advisor. <strong>Education Abroad: No more than two courses (8 units) may count toward upper-division requirements.</strong> All courses for the minor must be taken on a lettergrade basis, and an overall gradepoint average of 2.0 is required in upper division courses used for the minor.</p>
<h2 style="text-align: center;">THE HONORS PROGRAM</h2>
<p>To enter the honors program, in addition to having a minimum overall gradepoint average of 3.3, majors must have completed at least 20 upper division units in the major with a minimum grade point average of 3.5. Candidates must enroll in Italian Studies H195 for one semester in their senior year, during which they will carry out research and write an honors thesis under the guidance of a faculty member. Students who meet the gradepoint requirements must still first consult with the Faculty Advisor in order to pursue an honors thesis.</p>
	</div><!-- .entry-content-wrapper -->
</article><!-- #post-71 -->

	</div><!-- #main -->

									<header class="page-header">
						<h1 class="page-title">Hm. Looks like something went wrong&hellip;</h1>
				</header>
		<section id="content-container">
			
				<article id="post-0" class="post no-results not-found">

					<div class="entry-content">
						<p>It seems we can’t find what you’re looking for. If you are looking for a specific post, try searching up in the right-hand corner. Otherwise take a look at our most recent posts below.</p>
					</div><!-- .entry-content -->
				</article><!-- #post-0 -->

<article id="post-1839" class="group index-post-container">
				<figure class="the-thumbnail">
				<a href="http://italian.berkeley.edu/2016/11/16/2015-16-distinguished-teaching-award-barbara-spackman/" title="Permalink to 2015-16 Distinguished Teaching Award: Barbara Spackman" rel="bookmark">
					<img width="151" height="209" src="http://italian.berkeley.edu/wp-content/uploads/2014/08/spackman.jpg" class="attachment-index-thumb size-index-thumb wp-post-image" alt="" />				</a>
			</figure>
				<header class="index-header">
		<h1 class="index-title">
			<a href="http://italian.berkeley.edu/2016/11/16/2015-16-distinguished-teaching-award-barbara-spackman/" title="Permalink to 2015-16 Distinguished Teaching Award: Barbara Spackman" rel="bookmark">	
				2015-16 Distinguished Teaching Award: Barbara Spackman			</a>
		</h1>
	
	</header><!-- .entry-header -->

	<div class="index-content">
		<p>Congratulations to Professor <a href="http://italian.berkeley.edu/people/barbara-spackman/">Barbara Spackman</a>, Italian Studies and Comparative Literature, who received the 2015-2016 Distinguished Teaching Award for Senate Faculty Members.</p>
	</div><!-- .entry-content -->


</article><!-- #post-1839 -->




<article id="post-1279" class="group index-post-container">
		<header class="index-header">
		<h1 class="index-title">
			<a href="http://italian.berkeley.edu/2016/03/01/site-internship-program-apply-now/" title="Permalink to SITE Internship Program" rel="bookmark">	
				SITE Internship Program			</a>
		</h1>
	
	</header><!-- .entry-header -->

	<div class="index-content">
		<p>The <a href="http://siteprogram.wix.com/site">Study Intercultural Training Experience (SITE) internship</a> is a <strong>paid internship</strong> program based in Lombardy, Italy. It is aimed to recent graduates who have a good command of Italian and who are interested in working as teaching assistants in Lombard high schools for one or two semesters.</p>
<p> <a href="http://italian.berkeley.edu/2016/03/01/site-internship-program-apply-now/#more-1279" class="more-link"> &raquo;  read more  &raquo;</a></p>
	</div><!-- .entry-content -->


</article><!-- #post-1279 -->

jQuery(document).ready(function($){
    $(".gallery img").each(function(){
        var alt = $(this).attr("alt");
        $(this).parent().attr("title",function(i,val){
            return val == alt ? "" : alt;
        });
    });
});

<article id="post-85" class="group post-container entry-content">
	
				
	<header class="entry-header">
		<h1 class="entry-title">Resources for Italian Undergraduates</h1>
	</header><!-- .entry-header -->

	<div class="entry-content-wrapper">
		<ul>
<li><a href="http://hsp.berkeley.edu/">Haas Scholars Program</a></li>
<li><a href="http://research.berkeley.edu/urap/">Undergraduate Research Apprenticeship Program</a> (URAP)</li>
<li><a href="http://surf.berkeley.edu/">Summer Undergraduate Research Fellowships</a> (SURF)</li>
<li><a href="https://career.berkeley.edu/International/International.stm">Campus Career Center: International Career Field</a></li>
<li><a href="http://surf.berkeley.edu/travel">Travel Grants for Undergraduate Research</a></li>
<li><a href="http://italian.berkeley.edu/undergraduate-program/language-study-and-placement/peer-tutoring/">Italian language Peer Tutors</a></li>
<li><a href="http://italian.berkeley.edu/undergraduate-program/site-internship-program/">Study Intercultural Training Experience Internship</a> (SITE)</li>
</ul>
	</div><!-- .entry-content-wrapper -->

        $(this).parent().attr("title",function(i,val){
            return val == alt ? "" : alt;

<article id="post-1267" class="group post-container entry-content">
	
				
	<header class="entry-header">
		<h1 class="entry-title">SITE Internship Program</h1>
	</header><!-- .entry-header -->

	<div class="entry-content-wrapper">
		<p>The <a href="http://siteprogram.wix.com/site">Study Intercultural Training Experience (SITE) internship</a> is a <strong>paid internship</strong> program based in Lombardy, Italy. It is aimed to recent graduates who have a good command of Italian and who are interested in working as teaching assistants in Lombard high schools for one or two semesters.</p>
<p>If you are interested in perfecting your knowledge and understanding of Italian language and culture, while gaining valuable teaching experience abroad, this program is for you!</p>
<p>This great opportunity for linguistic and intercultural exchange is open to seniors and to former students who have graduated from UC Berkeley within the last 18 months. Students enrolled in a MA or PhD program of Italian language and culture can also apply.</p>
<p><a href="http://siteprogram.wix.com/site#!requirements/s5knb">Eligibility and Requirements</a></p>
<p><a href="http://siteprogram.wix.com/site#!how-to-apply/ikfng">How to Apply</a></p>
<p>There are two phases in the application.</p>
<p>1. The initial internal selection of applicants will be held at the Department of Italian Studies at UC Berkeley. The deadline to submit all your materials is <strong>March 6, 2017</strong>. The selection committee will review all the applications received and compile a list of nominations that it will share with the SITE program by the end of March 2017.</p>
<p>Materials to submit:</p>
<p><strong>a.</strong> A short <strong>statement of purpose </strong>explaining why you want to apply for the internship.<br />
<strong>b.</strong> A recent<strong> CV </strong>or <strong>resume </strong>(in English)<br />
<strong>c.</strong> Unofficial updated <strong>transcript</strong><br />
<strong>d.</strong> A detailed <strong>lesson plan </strong>in Italian that will serve as the basis for the essay requested by the SITE. The essay topics are:</p>
<p><em><u>Topic 1:</u></em> “Immagina di dovere svolgere una lezione sulla cucina americana in una classe seconda (età 15 anni) di livello pre-intermedio. Presenta una lezione-tipo concentrandoti specialmente sui contenuti, metodi e attività&#8221;.</p>
<p><em><u>Topic 2:</u></em> “Immagina di dover svolgere una lezione CLIL sui cambiamenti climatici per una classe terza (anni 16) di livello intermedio. Presenta una lezione-tipo concentrandoti specialmente sui contenuti, metodi e attività”.</p>
<p>Preference will be given to majors in Italian Studies, minors in Italian Studies, students who have teaching experience (peer tutoring at the department, for instance); students with a good command of the Italian language.</p>
<p><strong>Submit Phase 1 application materials to Giuliana Perco, <a href="mailto:gperco@berkeley.edu">gperco@berkeley.edu</a>.</strong></p>
<p>2. You will then officially <a href="http://siteprogram.wix.com/site#!how-to-apply/ikfng">apply to the SITE program</a> by <strong>March 20, 2017 </strong>(please note that the deadline is midnight <strong>EST</strong>).</p>
<p>With any questions, please contact the Italian language program coordinator, <a href="mailto:gperco@berkeley.edu">Dr. Giuliana Perco.</a></p>
<p>Testimonial from current participant Marley Ummel, an Italian Studies alumnus:</p>
<blockquote><p>The SITE internship has been a wonderful experience that I highly recommend it to anyone who has an interest in becoming a teacher. Of all my teaching experiences, this was the most similar to the actual profession; at my school I would be given a topic, but it was my job to create the lesson plan. I taught at a Liceo Scientifico in each class of each of the five years. I can tell you that teenagers are teenagers, regardless of where in the world you are. In general it was a pleasant experience and we were able to have fun and engage with each other, but there were also kids who make you feel like talking to a wall. It&#8217;s good to read about strategies and talk to other teachers about their experience, but nothing compares to the ability to just try things out for myself to see what works.<br />
In addition to the teaching experience, you&#8217;re living in a new country independently. The change to post-grad life is a big change, and adding the cultural and social change of a different country can be overwhelming for some people, but if you look around and try new things you&#8217;ll quickly build a new network around you. Like many things, what you will get out of this experience depends on how much work you put in.</p></blockquote>
<p>Testimonial from former participant Arthur Lei, current graduate student in Italian Studies:</p>
<blockquote><p>If I could summarize my experience in the program in one sentence, this is what I would say: &#8220;<i>Chi insegna, impara</i>.&#8221;</p>
<div>In this program, you will be immersed every day in a real-life teaching situation. You will not only improve your understanding of Italian language but deepen and enrich your understanding of Italian culture and gain a perspective that other study abroad experiences will rarely afford you. In my case, I taught English lessons in a middle school in Legnano; every day, I co-planned lessons and activities that helped students improve their English and understanding of the American experience. Working at the school, I not only found colleagues but dear friends.</div>
<div></div>
<div>I highly recommend this unique learning and language immersion experience to anyone who wants to be challenged and rewarded.</div>
</blockquote>
<div>Testimonial from current SITE participant Cynthia Columbus, who has elected to teach in Italy through SITE for two consecutive years:</div>
<div>
<blockquote>
<div>Insegno in un liceo a Milano e lavoro con studenti del primo, secondo, terzo, quarto e quinto anno. Lavoro con alcune classi una volta alla settimana e con altre una volta ogni due settimane. Collaboro con i miei colleghi per preparare le lezioni ma ho molta libertà di scegliere le attività che faccio con i ragazzi. Con quelli del primo e del secondo anno faccio grammatica, esercizi, dialoghi e conversazione. Con quelli più grandi discuto di argomenti più complessi e ogni tanto faccio una lezione sulla letteratura, la cultura o la storia americana. A volte guardiamo anche  film. Una volta per esempio abbiamo parlato della guerra civile e poi abbiamo guardato il film &#8220;Glory&#8221;.</div>
<div></div>
<div>Sono contenta di esser migliorata come insegnante. Però, durante questi due anni con SITE ho anche imparato a creare una comunità mia in una città diversa. Non ho un campus come all&#8217;università, ma ho trovato modi miei per fare amicizia e per tenermi occupata. Per esempio faccio parte di un &#8216;language exchange&#8217; settimanale ad un pub vicino a casa mia. C&#8217;è anche un gruppo su Facebook per gli insegnanti di SITE che usiamo per organizzare incontri. Grazie a questa esperienza, mi sento molto più indipendente rispetto a prima!</div>
</blockquote>
</div>
	</div><!-- .entry-content-wrapper -->
</article><!-- #post-1267 -->

        $(this).parent().attr("title",function(i,val){
            return val == alt ? "" : alt;
        });
    });
});

<article id="post-230" class="group post-container entry-content">
	
				
	<header class="entry-header">
		<h1 class="entry-title">Transfer Information</h1>
	</header><!-- .entry-header -->

	<div class="entry-content-wrapper">
		<p>The Department welcomes interested transfer students into its courses, and encourages them to choose Italian Studies as a major or minor. Many of our most successful students, including past winners of the annual departmental citation for outstanding achievement by a graduating senior, have begun their Berkeley careers as transfer students.</p>
<p>Click <a href="http://admissions.berkeley.edu/" target="_blank">here</a> for information about admission to Berkeley as a transfer student.</p>
<p>If you have taken lower-division Italian courses at a California community college, and want to know whether they will be transferable to Berkeley, you can find this out by using the statewide <a href="http://www.assist.org/web-assist/welcome.html" target="_blank">student transfer information Web site</a>. If you are not sure how well your background in Italian will equip you for study in the Department, you should consult the <a href="mailto:issaug@berkeley.edu">Undergraduate Student Services Advisor</a> or (for placement in language courses) the <a href="mailto:gperco@berkeley.edu">Language Program Coordinator</a>.</p>
<p>If you are a transfer student considering a major in Italian Studies, you should talk to the Undergraduate Adviser as soon as possible after you arrive at Berkeley. The College of Letters and Science has strict deadlines for declaration of a major by incoming transfer students, and the Department stands ready to help you comply with College regulations. For information on requirements for the major, click <a href="http://italian.berkeley.edu/undergraduate-program/majors-and-minors/">here</a>.</p>
<p>If you plan to minor in Italian Studies, you should talk to the Undergraduate Adviser no later than the beginning of the semester in which you plan to graduate. Students interested in the minor should plan an intent to minor with the Undergraduate Student Services Advisor. Click <a href="http://italian.berkeley.edu/undergraduate-program/majors-and-minors/#minor">here</a> for information on requirements for the minor.</p>
	</div><!-- .entry-content-wrapper -->
</article><!-- #post-230 -->

										</div>
			</div><!-- #content -->



	</div><!-- #main -->

<article id="post-576" class="group post-container entry-content">
	
				
	<header class="entry-header">
		<h1 class="entry-title">Undergraduate Student Learning Initiative</h1>
	</header><!-- .entry-header -->

	<div class="entry-content-wrapper">
		<p><strong>Goals</strong></p>
<p>In response to the Undergraduate Student Learning Initiative (USLI), we have articulated the goals of our undergraduate program and major as follows:</p>
<ul type="disc">
<li>Develop proficiency, approximating to that of an educated native speaker, in speaking, reading, writing, and comprehending Italian;</li>
<li>Be broadly familiar with the historical development of Italian culture from the Middle Ages to the present day;</li>
<li>Acquire detailed familiarity, through intensive and focused study. with a chronologically and generically disparate selection of cultural phenomena connected with Italy and the history of their critical and social reception;</li>
<li>Develop advanced skills in the critical analysis of literary texts and other cultural materials (e.g. films, paintings, musical compositions, historical documents, critical theories, social practices);</li>
<li>Have awareness and experience of a variety of approaches to the study of Italian culture, as practiced in both the humanities and the social sciences, and of the ways in which these may intersect to generate interdisciplinary study;</li>
<li>Learn to conduct research, i.e. to gather and evaluate evidence relating to a hypothesis and construct an argument using it;</li>
<li>Learn to assess the validity of evidence-based argumentation conducted by others;</li>
<li>Be aware of, and scrupulously practice, ethics-based protocols of citation etc. in academic research and writing;</li>
<li>Write clearly, accurately, and persuasively in both Italian and English;</li>
<li>Where practically possible, encounter contemporary Italian culture directly through study or travel in Italy. In this respect, study abroad might well constitute a capstone experience.</li>
<li>Develop a sense of the study of Italian culture not merely as an end in itself but as an integral part of a potentially unbounded set of processes and relationships through the exploration of which thinking human beings engage with the world they inhabit.</li>
</ul>
<p><strong>Relationship between goals and program</strong><br />
We view the relationship between these goals and our current curriculum as follows:</p>
<ul type="disc">
<li>Development of language skills is assured by the lower-division sequence of language courses (1, 2, 3, 4, and 12), taken in the first four semesters, and by the upper-division sequence (101A-101B), intended to be taken in the junior year and required for the major.It is further reinforced by the provision of numerous upper-division electives taught through the medium of Italian, at least four of which (along with 101A and 101B) must be taken for the major.</li>
<li>Broad familiarity with the historical development of Italian culture from the Middle Ages to the present day is attained through the recommended lower-division survey course (40) and the upper-division introductions to Italian literature (104) and culture (103), one of which is taught each semester, both of which are recommended for majors in their junior year, and one of which is required for completion of the major.</li>
<li>Intensive focused study of cultural phenomena, development of advanced skills in critical analysis, awareness and experience of interdisciplinary approaches, and practice in research and writing skills are obtained from all other upper-division courses in the department (or cross-listed and other approved courses elsewhere), whether taught in Italian or English.For students interested in a &#8220;capstone experience&#8221; they all culminate in thesis courses normally taken in the last semester before graduation.</li>
<li>Study and travel in Italy are encouraged by the department, usually in collaboration with the UC Education Abroad Program; up to twelve units of upper-division work on Italian topics taken on EAP/Italy may be counted toward satisfaction of major requirements. Intending majors commonly satisfy their junior-year course requirements (101A-101B, 103 or 104) entirely or partially in this way.The department is also normally sympathetic, where pedagogically appropriate and consonant with College and University policy, to requests for non-EAP study abroad to be accepted toward completion of major requirements.</li>
</ul>
	</div><!-- .entry-content-wrapper -->
</article><!-- #post-576 -->

										</div>

<header id="site-header" class="undergraduate wideness" role="banner">
	 <h1><a href="http://italian.berkeley.edu">  Who to See for Advising</a></h1>
			<nav id="main-nav" role="navigation">
				<div class="menu-header-menu-container"><ul id="menu-header-menu" class="sf-menu"><li id="menu-item-1554" class="menu-item menu-item-type-post_type menu-item-object-page menu-item-has-children menu-item-1554"><a href="http://italian.berkeley.edu/news-events/upcoming-events/">News &#038; Events</a>
<ul class="sub-menu">
	<li id="menu-item-1558" class="menu-item menu-item-type-post_type menu-item-object-page menu-item-1558"><a href="http://italian.berkeley.edu/news-events/">News</a></li>
	<li id="menu-item-1551" class="menu-item menu-item-type-post_type menu-item-object-page menu-item-1551"><a href="http://italian.berkeley.edu/news-events/upcoming-events/">Upcoming Events</a></li>
	<li id="menu-item-1537" class="menu-item menu-item-type-post_type menu-item-object-page menu-item-1537"><a href="http://italian.berkeley.edu/news-events/annual-events/">Annual Events</a></li>

</ul>
</li>
<li id="menu-item-1418" class="menu-item menu-item-type-taxonomy menu-item-object-people-category menu-item-has-children menu-item-1418"><a href="http://italian.berkeley.edu/people-category/core-faculty/">People</a>
<ul class="sub-menu">
	<li id="menu-item-1427" class="menu-item menu-item-type-taxonomy menu-item-object-people-category menu-item-1427"><a href="http://italian.berkeley.edu/people-category/core-faculty/">Core Faculty</a></li>
	<li id="menu-item-1430" class="menu-item menu-item-type-taxonomy menu-item-object-people-category menu-item-1430"><a href="http://italian.berkeley.edu/people-category/lecturers-and-gsis/">Lecturers and GSIs</a></li>
	<li id="menu-item-1426" class="menu-item menu-item-type-taxonomy menu-item-object-people-category menu-item-1426"><a href="http://italian.berkeley.edu/people-category/affiliated-faculty/">Affiliated Faculty</a></li>

<article id="post-69" class="group post-container entry-content">
	
				
	<header class="entry-header">
		<h1 class="entry-title">Who to See for Advising</h1>
	</header><!-- .entry-header -->

	<div class="entry-content-wrapper">
		<p>The Department offers complete advising services for undergraduates (including language placement; majors, double majors &amp; minors; transfer students; summer sessions; breadth requirements and R&amp;C in English; study abroad opportunities).</p>
<p>Students needing placement within the language program should consult with <a href="http://italian.berkeley.edu/people/giuliana-perco/" target="_blank" rel="noopener noreferrer">Dr. Giuliana Perco</a>, Language Program Coordinator. Dr. Perco may also be consulted about Study Abroad opportunities, though students should also seek advice from the campus EAP office (<a href="mailto:scottmc@berkeley.edu" target="_blank" rel="noopener noreferrer">Scott McElhinney</a>).</p>
<p>Students who wish to discuss declaring a major, double major, or minor in Italian Studies, transfer students with questions about the program, should consult both with the faculty Director of Undergraduate Studies (<a href="http://italian.berkeley.edu/people/diego-pirillo/" target="_blank" rel="noopener noreferrer">Professor Diego Pirillo</a>) and the Undergraduate Student Services Advisor (<a href="http://italian.berkeley.edu/people/526-2/">Amanda Minafo</a>). Students seeking to fulfill R&amp;C or breadth requirements, or other English language offerings on Italian topics should consult the website and/or speak to Ms. Minafo. To inquire about the Biasin Traveling Fellowship for current and recently graduated students, contact Prof. Diego Pirillo.</p>
	</div><!-- .entry-content-wrapper -->
</article><!-- #post-69 -->

										</div>

        $(this).parent().attr("title",function(i,val){
            return val == alt ? "" : alt;
        });
    });
});
